University of Montenegro governance, including academic title processes and research funding allocation, requires transparency improvements beyond what a stable CPI score reflects.
Brain drain continues despite the improved regional ranking, as the absolute corruption perception level remains a push factor for educated youth emigrating to EU countries with scores above 60.
Education procurement (textbooks, infrastructure, digital equipment) remains an area of elevated corruption risk that requires sector-specific oversight mechanisms.
recommendations: Leverage the positive CPI momentum to push for an education-sector-specific integrity assessment, potentially in partnership with the Agency for Prevention of Corruption and international organizations like the OECD or Council of Europe.
Introduce fully transparent, merit-based teacher recruitment portals with public scoring criteria for all primary and secondary school appointments, reducing municipal-level discretion.

Strengthen University of Montenegro governance by mandating public disclosure of academic appointment committee decisions, research grant allocations, and procurement contracts above defined thresholds.
Use the favorable regional ranking to actively negotiate expanded Erasmus+ quotas and Horizon Europe associated country benefits, positioning education as a flagship sector for EU integration.
Develop anti-corruption modules within the existing civic education curriculum for secondary schools, building a culture of integrity from the student level.

Commission an independent audit of education procurement processes over the past three years, covering textbook selection, school construction, and ICT equipment, to identify sector-specific corruption vulnerabilities.

counter_proposal.title: Education Integrity and Transparency Action Plan
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than treating the CPI ranking as a passive indicator, the Ministry of Education would propose an active Education Integrity and Transparency Action Plan that translates the national anti-corruption momentum into concrete education sector reforms. This plan would focus on three pillars: transparent human resource management in schools and universities, open procurement for all education investments, and integrity education within the curriculum itself.
key_changes: Establish a centralized, digital teacher recruitment platform under the Ministry of Education with standardized scoring rubrics, removing sole municipal discretion from hiring decisions for primary and secondary schools.
Require all University of Montenegro faculties to publish annual transparency reports covering staff appointments, research funding distribution, and financial statements in machine-readable format.
Create an Education Procurement Oversight Board with civil society participation to review all education contracts above 50,000 euros.
Integrate anti-corruption and institutional integrity content into the secondary school civic education curriculum, aligned with Council of Europe education standards.
Pilot an anonymous whistleblower mechanism for education sector employees (teachers, administrative staff, university workers) in partnership with the Agency for Prevention of Corruption.
expected_benefits: Improved teacher quality through genuinely merit-based recruitment, directly raising classroom instruction standards.
Greater international confidence in Montenegrin higher education institutions, supporting research partnerships and reducing academic brain drain.
More efficient use of the limited education budget by reducing procurement leakage and misallocation.
Strengthened EU accession position on Chapter 26 by demonstrating sector-specific governance improvements beyond aggregate indices.
Long-term cultural shift toward integrity among students who will become future professionals and public servants.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible within a 12-18 month timeline. The digital recruitment platform requires IT investment and legal amendments to the General Law on Education but builds on existing e-government infrastructure. University transparency reports can be mandated through amendments to the Law on Higher Education. Curriculum changes can be integrated into the next academic year cycle. The main political obstacle is resistance from municipal authorities and university faculties that benefit from current discretionary practices.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Akcioni plan za integritet i transparentnost u obrazovanju
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da se rang na CPI tretira kao pasivni pokazatelj, Ministarstvo prosvjete bi predložilo aktivan Akcioni plan za integritet i transparentnost u obrazovanju, koji nacionalni antikorupcijski zamah pretvara u konkretne reforme obrazovnog sektora. Ovaj plan bio bi zasnovan na tri stuba: transparentno upravljanje ljudskim resursima u školama i na univerzitetima, otvorene nabavke za sve obrazovne investicije i obrazovanje o integritetu u samom nastavnom planu i programu.
key_changes_mne: Uspostavljanje centralizovane digitalne platforme za zapošljavanje nastavnika pri Ministarstvu prosvjete, sa standardizovanim kriterijumima ocjenjivanja, čime se uklanja isključiva diskrecija opština u odlukama o zapošljavanju u osnovnim i srednjim školama.

Obavezivanje svih fakulteta Univerziteta Crne Gore da objavljuju godišnje izvještaje o transparentnosti koji obuhvataju imenovanja zaposlenih, raspodjelu sredstava za istraživanje i finansijske izvještaje u mašinski čitljivom formatu.
Osnivanje Nadzornog odbora za nabavke u obrazovanju uz učešće civilnog društva, radi pregleda svih obrazovnih ugovora iznad 50.000 eura.
Uključivanje sadržaja o borbi protiv korupcije i institucionalnom integritetu u nastavni plan i program građanskog vaspitanja u srednjim školama, usklađeno sa obrazovnim standardima Savjeta Evrope.

Pilot-uvođenje anonimnog mehanizma za dojavu nepravilnosti za zaposlene u obrazovnom sektoru (nastavnike, administrativno osoblje, radnike na univerzitetima) u partnerstvu sa Agencijom za sprečavanje korupcije.
expected_benefits_mne: Poboljšan kvalitet nastavnog kadra kroz istinski zaslugama zasnovano zapošljavanje, što neposredno podiže standarde nastave u učionicama.
Veće međunarodno povjerenje u crnogorske visokoškolske ustanove, uz podršku istraživačkim partnerstvima i smanjenje akademskog odljeva mozgova.
Efikasnije korišćenje ograničenog obrazovnog budžeta smanjivanjem gubitaka u nabavkama i pogrešne raspodjele sredstava.
Ojačana pozicija u procesu pristupanja EU po Poglavlju 26, demonstriranjem poboljšanja upravljanja specifičnih za sektor, izvan zbirnih indeksa.
Dugoročna kulturna promjena prema integritetu kod učenika koji će postati budući stručnjaci i državni službenici.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno ostvarivo u roku od 12 do 18 mjeseci. Digitalna platforma za zapošljavanje zahtijeva IT investicije i izmjene Opšteg zakona o obrazovanju, ali se nadovezuje na postojeću e-upravu infrastrukturu. Izvještaji o transparentnosti univerziteta mogu se uvesti izmjenama Zakona o visokom obrazovanju. Izmjene nastavnog plana i programa mogu se integrisati u naredni nastavni ciklus. Glavna politička prepreka je otpor opštinskih vlasti i univerzitetskih fakulteta koji imaju koristi od trenutnih diskrecijskih praksi.

assessments.summary_mne: Vodeća pozicija Crne Gore na Indeksu percepcije korupcije u Zapadnom Balkanu umjereno je pozitivan signal za sektor obrazovanja. Rezultat od 46/100 i dalje ukazuje na značajne izazove u borbi protiv korupcije koji direktno utiču na obrazovanje kroz netransparentne nabavke, zapošljavanje nastavnog i univerzitetskog osoblja bez zasluga i oslabljeno povjerenje javnosti u institucije. Ipak, održavanje stabilnosti dok se globalni trendovi pogoršavaju, uz regionalno liderstvo, pruža osnovu za privlačenje sredstava EU za obrazovanje u okviru pretpristupnog procesa i unapređenje međunarodnih akademskih partnerstava.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Rang na Indeksu percepcije korupcije pozitivan je, ali nedovoljan pokazatelj za reformu obrazovanja. Iako regionalno liderstvo u transparentnosti podržava kredibilitet u procesu pristupanja EU i može olakšati angažman u okviru programa Erasmus+ i Horizont Evropa, rezultat od 46/100 znači da korupcija i dalje narušava zapošljavanje nastavnika, upravljanje univerzitetima i pravednu raspodjelu resursa. Ministarstvo prosvjete treba da iskoristi ovaj zamah za sprovođenje antikorupcijskih mjera specifičnih za sektor, umjesto da rang tretira kao razlog za samozadovoljstvo.
key_concerns_mne: Rezultat od 46/100 na Indeksu percepcije korupcije i dalje svrstava Crnu Goru ispod praga koji se obično vezuje za dobro funkcionisanje upravljanja obrazovanjem, što znači da korupcijski rizici u zapošljavanju nastavnika, univerzitetskim imenovanjima i nabavkama ostaju značajni.
Rang lista je indeks zasnovan na percepciji i ne mjeri stvarnu korupciju u sektoru obrazovanja konkretno; transparentnost na nivou sektora može biti lošija ili bolja od nacionalnog prosjeka.
Zapošljavanje nastavnika bez kriterijuma zasluga na opštinskom nivou ostaje uporan problem koji ovaj indikator na nacionalnom nivou ne obuhvata niti rješava.

Upravljanje Univerzitetom Crne Gore, uključujući procese dodjele akademskih zvanja i raspodjelu sredstava za istraživanje, zahtijeva poboljšanja u transparentnosti koja prevazilaze ono što odražava stabilan rezultat na Indeksu percepcije korupcije.
Odliv mozgova se nastavlja uprkos poboljšanom regionalnom rangu, jer apsolutni nivo percepcije korupcije ostaje faktor koji podstiče emigraciju obrazovane mladeži u zemlje EU sa rezultatima iznad 60.
Nabavke u obrazovanju (udžbenici, infrastruktura, digitalna oprema) ostaju oblast povećanog korupcijskog rizika koja zahtijeva mehanizme nadzora specifične za sektor.
recommendations_mne: Iskoristiti pozitivan zamah Indeksa percepcije korupcije kako bi se pokrenula procjena integriteta specifična za sektor obrazovanja, potencijalno u partnerstvu sa Agencijom za sprječavanje korupcije i međunarodnim organizacijama poput OECD-a ili Savjeta Evrope.

Uvesti potpuno transparentne portale za zapošljavanje nastavnika zasnovane na zaslugama, s javnim kriterijumima bodovanja za sva imenovanja u osnovnim i srednjim školama, čime se smanjuje diskrecija na opštinskom nivou.

Ojačati upravljanje Univerzitetom Crne Gore uvođenjem obaveze javnog objavljivanja odluka komisija za akademska imenovanja, raspodjele istraživačkih grantova i ugovora o nabavci iznad utvrđenih pragova.

Iskoristiti povoljan regionalni rang za aktivno pregovaranje o proširenim kvotama u okviru programa Erasmus+ i beneficijama pridružene zemlje u okviru programa Horizont Evropa, pozicionirajući obrazovanje kao ključni sektor u procesu evropskih integracija.
Razviti antikorupcijske module u okviru postojećeg nastavnog plana građanskog obrazovanja za srednje škole, izgrađujući kulturu integriteta na nivou učenika.

Naručiti nezavisnu reviziju procesa nabavki u obrazovanju za protekle tri godine, obuhvatajući odabir udžbenika, izgradnju škola i informatičku opremu, kako bi se identifikovale korupcijske ranjivosti specifične za sektor.

assessments.summary: Montenegro's top ranking in the Western Balkans on the 2025 Corruption Perceptions Index is a welcome development that reinforces the country's narrative as a regional frontrunner in EU accession. However, a score of 46/100 remains well below the EU average and signals that deep, structural anti-corruption reforms -- central to Chapters 23 and 24 -- are far from complete. The stability of the score, while positive against a worsening global backdrop, also means no measurable improvement was achieved year-on-year, which the European Commission will note in its next progress report.
assessments.executive_summary: Montenegro's best-in-region CPI ranking is a positive signal for EU accession credibility but the absolute score of 46/100 remains insufficient to meet closing benchmarks for Chapters 23 and 24. The Ministry urges the government to treat this as a baseline, not an achievement, and to accelerate judicial reform and anti-corruption track records.
assessments.reasoning:
From an EU integration standpoint, the CPI result must be assessed on two levels: relative regional positioning and absolute reform adequacy. On the first level, Montenegro's 65th-place ranking and its lead over all Western Balkan peers -- including Serbia at 116th and Albania at 91st -- strengthens its political case as the most advanced candidate country. This positioning matters in Brussels, where comparative progress among Western Balkan states influences political will for enlargement. The fact that Montenegro scores only one point below Croatia (47), an EU member state, is a useful talking point in diplomatic engagement.

However, on the second and more consequential level, a score of 46 out of 100 is inadequate for a country seeking to close Chapters 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) and 24 (Justice, Freedom and Security). These chapters are governed by the 'new approach' methodology, meaning they are opened first and closed last, and require a demonstrated track record of results in fighting corruption and organized crime. The European Commission's annual reports have consistently flagged the need for a credible track record of final convictions in high-level corruption cases, stronger asset declaration verification, more effective work by the Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK), and genuine independence of the judiciary from political influence. A static CPI score suggests that while the situation has not worsened, systemic improvements in these areas have not materialized to a degree visible to external evaluators.

The CPI is a composite index based on expert assessments and business surveys, not a direct measure of government policy. It reflects perceptions, which lag behind reforms. This means that even if Montenegro has adopted new legislation -- such as amendments to the Law on Prevention of Corruption or reforms to prosecution structures -- these have not yet translated into perceived improvements. The Commission will take note of the CPI but will rely more heavily on its own assessment, GRECO reports, and specific benchmarks tied to the interim benchmarks for Chapters 23 and 24.

Regarding IPA funding, a stable anti-corruption perception is neither a risk nor a catalyst. IPA III programming for 2021-2027 includes significant allocations for rule of law and fundamental rights. Montenegro's continued access to these funds is contingent on reform momentum, not just stable rankings. The Commission could interpret stagnation as a sign that IPA-funded technical assistance and institution-building projects are not delivering sufficient impact, which could affect future programming priorities.

The regional dimension is also relevant for the Berlin Process and Western Balkans summits, where Montenegro's credibility as a reform leader facilitates its advocacy role. However, leading a region where the average CPI score is well below 50 is a low bar. Montenegro should benchmark itself against EU member states, not regional peers, if it is serious about accession readiness.
key_concerns: A CPI score of 46/100 remains significantly below the EU member state average of approximately 64, indicating a substantial gap that must be closed before Chapters 23 and 24 can be credibly assessed for closure.
Year-on-year stagnation in the score means no measurable improvement in perceived corruption, which the European Commission will flag as insufficient reform momentum.
The CPI does not measure track records of prosecutions and convictions in high-level corruption cases -- the single most important benchmark the Commission monitors under Chapter 23.
Risk that the government uses the regional ranking for political messaging while deprioritizing the harder structural reforms required by the accession process.
IPA-funded rule of law projects may face scrutiny if external indicators show no improvement despite significant EU financial assistance.
recommendations: Avoid treating the CPI ranking as evidence of reform success in EU accession communications; instead, present it as a baseline that validates the direction of travel while acknowledging the gap to EU standards.
Accelerate efforts to build a credible track record of final convictions in high-level corruption cases, which is the Commission's primary metric under the interim benchmarks for Chapter 23.

Strengthen the operational independence and resources of the Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK) and the Special State Prosecutor's Office (SDT) to ensure that institutional capacity matches legislative frameworks.
Request a targeted peer review mission under TAIEX or bilateral cooperation with EU member states that have successfully improved their CPI scores post-accession, such as Estonia or Latvia.
Integrate CPI-relevant indicators into the national anti-corruption strategy monitoring framework, ensuring that perception-based metrics complement the Commission's track-record-based assessment.
Use Montenegro's regional lead as diplomatic leverage in Brussels to advocate for acceleration of the accession timeline, while pairing this advocacy with concrete reform deliverables.

counter_proposal.title: From Perception Leadership to Reform Track Record
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than leveraging the CPI result primarily for political communication, the Ministry of EU Integration would use this moment to launch a structured Action Plan for Chapter 23 Closing Benchmarks, tying the positive perception data to a concrete timeline for delivering the prosecutorial and judicial reform results that the European Commission requires. The plan would set quarterly milestones for high-level corruption cases, asset recovery outcomes, and judicial integrity indicators, and would be shared with the Commission as a voluntary commitment ahead of the next intergovernmental conference.
key_changes: Develop a Chapter 23 Closing Benchmark Delivery Plan with quarterly targets for final convictions, asset seizures, and institutional performance indicators.
Establish a joint monitoring mechanism between the Ministry of Justice, SDT, ASK, and the EU Integration office to track progress against Commission benchmarks in real time.
Commission an independent gap analysis comparing Montenegro's anti-corruption institutional framework against the top-performing EU member states, not Western Balkan peers.
Present the CPI result to the European Commission alongside a voluntary reform acceleration commitment at the next bilateral meeting or intergovernmental conference.
expected_benefits: Demonstrates to the Commission that Montenegro distinguishes between perception metrics and substantive reform outcomes, increasing credibility.
Creates an internal accountability mechanism that prevents reform fatigue or complacency following positive external rankings.
Positions Montenegro to request opening of new interim benchmarks or advancement in the accession process based on demonstrated delivery, not just rankings.
Strengthens the case for continued and potentially increased IPA III funding for rule of law by showing concrete reform trajectory tied to EU benchmarks.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The proposed actions rely on existing institutional structures and do not require new legislation. The main requirement is political will to shift from a communications-oriented response to a reform-delivery-oriented one. The Ministry of EU Integration has the convening authority to coordinate across institutions, and the Commission would likely welcome such a voluntary commitment.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Od liderstva u percepciji do stvarnih reformskih rezultata
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da rezultat CPI koristi prvenstveno za političku komunikaciju, Ministarstvo evropskih integracija bi ovaj trenutak iskoristilo za pokretanje strukturiranog Akcionog plana za zatvaranje mjerila iz Poglavlja 23, povezujući pozitivne podatke o percepciji s konkretnim vremenskim okvirom za postizanje reformskih rezultata u oblasti tužilaštva i pravosuđa koje zahtijeva Evropska komisija. Plan bi utvrdio kvartalne prekretnice za slučajeve korupcije na visokom nivou, ishode povrata imovine i pokazatelje integriteta pravosuđa, a bio bi dostavljen Komisiji kao dobrovoljna obaveza uoči naredne međuvladine konferencije.
key_changes_mne: Izraditi Plan realizacije mjerila za zatvaranje Poglavlja 23 s kvartalnim ciljevima za pravosnažne presude, zapljenu imovine i pokazatelje institucionalnih performansi.
Uspostaviti zajednički mehanizam praćenja između Ministarstva pravde, SDT-a, ASK-a i Ureda za evropske integracije radi praćenja napretka u odnosu na mjerila Komisije u realnom vremenu.

Naručiti nezavisnu analizu nedostataka kojom bi se institucionalni okvir Crne Gore za borbu protiv korupcije uporedio s državama članicama EU s najboljim rezultatima, a ne s partnerima sa Zapadnog Balkana.
Predstaviti rezultat CPI Evropskoj komisiji zajedno s dobrovoljnom obavezom ubrzanja reformi na narednom bilateralnom sastanku ili međuvladinoj konferenciji.
expected_benefits_mne: Komisiji se demonstrira da Crna Gora pravi razliku između metrika percepcije i suštinskih reformskih rezultata, čime se povećava kredibilitet.
Stvara se interni mehanizam odgovornosti koji sprječava reformski zamor ili samozadovoljstvo nakon pozitivnih međunarodnih rangiranja.
Crna Gora se pozicionira da zatraži otvaranje novih privremenih mjerila ili napredovanje u procesu pristupanja na osnovu dokazanih rezultata, a ne samo rangova.
Jača se argumentacija za nastavak, i potencijalno povećanje, IPA III finansiranja za vladavinu prava, pokazivanjem konkretne reformske trajektorije vezane za mjerila EU.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Predložene mjere oslanjaju se na postojeće institucionalne strukture i ne zahtijevaju donošenje novih zakonskih propisa. Glavni preduslov je politička volja da se od komunikacijski orijentisanog pristupa pređe na pristup usmjeren na isporuku reformi. Ministarstvo evropskih integracija ima ovlašćenje koordinacije između institucija, a Komisija bi takvu dobrovoljnu obavezu vjerovatno pozdravila.

assessments.summary_mne: Vodeća pozicija Crne Gore u Zapadnom Balkanu na Indeksu percepcije korupcije za 2025. godinu predstavlja dobrodošao pomak koji učvršćuje narativ o zemlji kao regionalnom predvodniku u procesu pristupanja EU. Međutim, ocjena od 46/100 i dalje je znatno ispod prosjeka EU i signalizira da su duboke, strukturalne antikorupcijske reforme – ključne za Poglavlja 23 i 24 – daleko od završetka. Stabilnost ocjene, iako pozitivna na fonu pogoršanja globalne situacije, istovremeno znači da nije ostvaren nikakav mjerljiv napredak u odnosu na prethodnu godinu, što će Evropska komisija zabilježiti u svom narednom izvještaju o napretku.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Vodeći regionalni plasman Crne Gore na CPI-u predstavlja pozitivan signal za kredibilitet u procesu pristupanja EU, međutim apsolutna ocjena od 46/100 i dalje nije dovoljna za ispunjavanje mjerila za zatvaranje Poglavlja 23 i 24. Ministarstvo podstiče Vladu da ovo tretira kao polaznu osnovu, a ne kao dostignuće, te da ubrza pravosudne reforme i izgradnju antikorupcijskih rezultata.
key_concerns_mne: Ocjena CPI od 46/100 i dalje je znatno ispod prosjeka država članica EU koji iznosi oko 64, što ukazuje na značajan jaz koji mora biti premošćen prije nego što Poglavlja 23 i 24 budu mogli vjerodostojno biti razmatrana za zatvaranje.
Stagnacija ocjene iz godine u godinu znači da nema mjerljivog napretka u percepciji korupcije, što će Evropska komisija označiti kao nedovoljan reformski zamah.
CPI ne mjeri evidentiranost gonjenja i osuda u predmetima korupcije na visokom nivou – što je jedan od najvažnijih pokazatelja koje Komisija prati u okviru Poglavlja 23.
Postoji rizik da Vlada koristi regionalni plasman u svrhu političkog marketinga, zanemarujući pritom teže strukturalne reforme koje zahtijeva proces pristupanja.
Projekti vladavine prava finansirani iz IPA fondova mogu biti izloženi kritici ukoliko spoljni pokazatelji ne bilježe napredak uprkos značajnoj finansijskoj podršci EU.
recommendations_mne: Izbjegavati predstavljanje plasmana na CPI-u kao dokaza uspjeha reformi u komunikaciji o pristupanju EU; umjesto toga, prikazati ga kao polaznu osnovu koja potvrđuje smjer kretanja, uz istovremeno prepoznavanje jaza u odnosu na standarde EU.
Ubrzati napore ka izgradnji vjerodostojne evidencije pravosnažnih osuda u predmetima korupcije na visokom nivou, što je primarni pokazatelj Komisije u okviru prelaznih mjerila za Poglavlje 23.
Ojačati operativnu nezavisnost i resurse Agencije za sprječavanje korupcije (ASK) i Specijalnog državnog tužilaštva (SDT), kako bi institucionalni kapaciteti bili usklađeni sa zakonodavnim okvirima.

Zatražiti ciljanu misiju stručne provjere u okviru TAIEX-a ili bilateralne saradnje sa državama članicama EU koje su uspješno poboljšale svoje CPI ocjene nakon pristupanja, kao što su Estonija ili Latvija.

Integrisati pokazatelje relevantne za CPI u okvir praćenja nacionalne antikorupcijske strategije, osiguravajući da pokazatelji zasnovani na percepciji dopunjuju procjenu Komisije zasnovanu na evidenciji rezultata.

Iskoristiti regionalno vodstvo Crne Gore kao diplomatsku polugu u Briselu za zalaganje za ubrzanje vremenskog okvira pristupanja, uz istovremeno vezivanje te zagovaračke aktivnosti za konkretne reformske rezultate.

assessments.summary: Montenegro's position as the best-ranked Western Balkans country on the 2025 Corruption Perceptions Index, with a score of 46/100, is a positive signal for the Ministry of Finance. While this is not a government decision per se, it reflects institutional conditions that directly affect fiscal credibility, borrowing costs, foreign direct investment attraction, and EU accession prospects. However, a score of 46 still places Montenegro below the EU average and signals that significant governance deficiencies persist, which continue to impose a measurable fiscal cost through higher risk premiums and lost investment.
assessments.executive_summary: Montenegro's top Western Balkans CPI ranking is a modest but meaningful positive for fiscal credibility, investor confidence, and EU accession optics. However, a score of 46/100 remains well below EU standards, and the Ministry urges that this relative success be leveraged into concrete anti-corruption reforms in public procurement and tax administration to unlock tangible fiscal gains.
assessments.reasoning:
From a fiscal policy perspective, corruption perception indices have a well-documented correlation with sovereign borrowing costs, foreign direct investment inflows, and the efficiency of public expenditure. Montenegro's stable score of 46, while the global average deteriorated, represents relative improvement and sends a constructive signal to international capital markets and rating agencies such as Moody's and S&P, which incorporate governance indicators into sovereign risk assessments.

For a country that uses the euro without European Central Bank membership, Montenegro cannot use monetary policy tools to manage economic shocks. This makes fiscal credibility and investor confidence disproportionately important. A better corruption perception reduces the risk premium on government borrowing, which is significant given Montenegro's public debt-to-GDP ratio, which has hovered around 60-70% in recent years. Even a modest reduction in borrowing spreads on Eurobonds can translate into millions of euros in annual debt servicing savings.

Regarding foreign direct investment, Montenegro's position ahead of Serbia, Albania, and Bosnia and Herzegovina provides a competitive advantage in attracting FDI within the Western Balkans. International investors, particularly from the EU, routinely reference CPI scores in investment risk assessments. The tourism, energy, and real estate sectors, which are key drivers of Montenegrin growth, are particularly sensitive to perceived institutional quality.

On EU accession economics, the ranking supports Montenegro's narrative as the most advanced Western Balkans candidate. Chapters 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) and 24 (Justice, Freedom, and Security) are directly linked to anti-corruption performance, and progress on these chapters unlocks greater access to EU pre-accession funds (IPA III), which are a significant supplementary fiscal resource.

However, the Ministry must be candid: a score of 46 is far from satisfactory. The EU-27 average is approximately 64, and the Maastricht-era member states average above 70. Montenegro remains closer to countries like Kuwait, Armenia, and Senegal than to its EU aspirational peers. This gap implies that corruption continues to erode tax collection efficiency, inflate public procurement costs, and reduce the productivity of capital investment spending. Studies suggest that countries with CPI scores below 50 lose an estimated 5-15% of public procurement value to corruption-related inefficiencies. For Montenegro's budget of approximately 2 billion euros, this could represent 50 to 150 million euros in annual waste.

The tax system is also affected. Corruption perception correlates with tax morale and voluntary compliance. Montenegro's relatively low VAT collection efficiency and persistent grey economy, estimated at 25-35% of GDP, are partly attributable to weak institutional trust. Improving real anti-corruption performance, not just perception, would directly improve fiscal revenues without requiring rate increases.

Finally, this is a perception index, not a direct measure of corruption. The Ministry notes that perception can lag behind or run ahead of actual institutional reforms. The government should not treat this ranking as validation of the status quo but as a baseline from which to pursue measurable improvement.
key_concerns: A score of 46/100 remains approximately 18 points below the EU average, indicating a substantial governance gap that affects fiscal credibility and EU convergence.
The score has been stagnant rather than improving, suggesting that anti-corruption reforms have not yet produced measurable results beyond maintaining the status quo.
Corruption-related inefficiencies in public procurement likely cost the budget tens of millions of euros annually, reducing the effective impact of capital investment programs.
The persistent grey economy, linked to low institutional trust, continues to erode the tax base and limit fiscal space without recourse to tax rate increases.
Montenegro shares its ranking tier with countries that are not EU candidates, which undermines the narrative of convergence with European standards.
Perception indices can be volatile and influenced by media cycles; the government should not rely on this metric as a primary indicator of reform success.
recommendations: Commission an independent fiscal impact assessment of corruption on public procurement efficiency, tax collection, and capital investment returns to quantify the actual budgetary cost of the current CPI score.

Accelerate digitalization of tax administration and public procurement systems, including mandatory e-procurement for all contracts above 50,000 euros, to reduce discretionary decision-making and improve transparency.

Establish a dedicated anti-corruption unit within the Ministry of Finance focused on revenue leakage, illicit financial flows, and beneficial ownership transparency, aligned with EU Anti-Money Laundering Directive requirements.
Use the favorable regional ranking as a marketing asset in upcoming Eurobond issuances and investor roadshows to negotiate tighter spreads on sovereign debt.
Set a concrete target of reaching a CPI score of 50 by 2028 and 55 by 2030, with linked milestones in the EU accession negotiation framework for Chapters 23 and 24.
Strengthen cooperation with the State Audit Institution to ensure that budget execution audits are published promptly and that audit recommendations are tracked for implementation.

counter_proposal.title: From Perception to Fiscal Dividends: An Anti-Corruption Revenue Strategy
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than treating the CPI ranking as a communications achievement, the Ministry of Finance would anchor it in a concrete fiscal strategy that converts improved governance into measurable budget gains. This involves quantifying the fiscal cost of corruption, targeting the highest-loss areas (public procurement, tax compliance, state-owned enterprises), and setting binding CPI improvement targets linked to EU accession milestones and sovereign debt management objectives.
key_changes: Mandate full e-procurement for all public contracts and publish all contract data in open-data format to reduce procurement leakage by an estimated 5-10%.
Introduce a risk-based tax audit system using data analytics to target the grey economy, with a goal of increasing VAT collection efficiency by 3 percentage points within two years.
Create an inter-ministerial anti-corruption fiscal task force co-chaired by Finance and Justice, with quarterly reporting to Parliament on fiscal savings from anti-corruption measures.
Link sovereign debt communication strategy to governance improvements, presenting CPI trajectory data to rating agencies and investors as part of fiscal credibility narrative.
expected_benefits: Estimated 30 to 80 million euros in annual fiscal savings from improved procurement efficiency and reduced revenue leakage.
Lower sovereign borrowing costs through improved governance perception, potentially saving 5 to 15 million euros annually on debt servicing.
Stronger negotiating position on EU accession chapters, unlocking greater access to IPA III pre-accession funds.
Increased FDI inflows as Montenegro differentiates itself from regional competitors on governance quality.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility for the digitalization and procurement transparency measures, which can be implemented within 12-18 months using existing EU technical assistance programs. The tax administration reforms require 18-24 months for full deployment. The inter-ministerial task force can be established immediately by government decree. Overall, the proposal is achievable within a single government mandate and aligns with existing EU accession commitments.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Od percepcije do fiskalnih dividendi: Strategija prihoda u borbi protiv korupcije
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da se rang na CPI ljestvici tretira kao komunikacijski uspjeh, Ministarstvo finansija bi ga utemeljilo u konkretnoj fiskalnoj strategiji koja poboljšano upravljanje pretvara u mjerljive budžetske dobitke. To podrazumijeva kvantifikovanje fiskalnog troška korupcije, ciljanje oblasti s najvećim gubicima (javne nabavke, poreska usklađenost, državna preduzeća) i postavljanje obavezujućih ciljeva za poboljšanje CPI-a povezanih s ključnim tačkama pristupanja EU i ciljevima upravljanja državnim dugom.
key_changes_mne: Uvesti obaveznu potpunu e-nabavku za sve javne ugovore i objaviti sve podatke o ugovorima u formatu otvorenih podataka, kako bi se procurenje u nabavkama smanjilo za procijenjenih 5–10%.

Uvesti sistem poreskih revizija zasnovan na procjeni rizika, uz primjenu analitike podataka za ciljanje sive ekonomije, s ciljem povećanja efikasnosti naplate PDV-a za 3 procentna poena u roku od dvije godine.

Osnovati međuresornu radnu grupu za fiskalnu borbu protiv korupcije, na čijem čelu bi zajednički bili Ministarstvo finansija i Ministarstvo pravde, uz kvartalno izvještavanje Skupštini o fiskalnim uštedama ostvarenim kroz antikoruptivne mjere.

Povezati strategiju komunikacije o državnom dugu s poboljšanjima u upravljanju, prezentujući podatke o kretanju CPI-a agencijama za kreditni rejting i investitorima kao dio narativa o fiskalnoj vjerodostojnosti.
expected_benefits_mne: Procijenjene godišnje fiskalne uštede od 30 do 80 miliona eura zahvaljujući poboljšanoj efikasnosti nabavki i smanjenom curenju prihoda.
Niži troškovi državnog zaduživanja kroz poboljšanu percepciju upravljanja, s potencijalnom godišnjom uštedim od 5 do 15 miliona eura na servisiranju duga.
Jača pregovaračka pozicija u poglavljima pristupanja EU, čime se otvara veći pristup IPA III pretpristupnim fondovima.
Povećan priliv stranih direktnih investicija, jer Crna Gora ističe svoju prednost nad regionalnim konkurentima kada je riječ o kvalitetu upravljanja.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost mjera digitalizacije i transparentnosti nabavki, koje se mogu implementirati u roku od 12 do 18 mjeseci uz korišćenje postojećih programa tehničke pomoći EU. Reforme poreske administracije zahtijevaju 18 do 24 mjeseca za potpunu primjenu. Međuresorna radna grupa može se osnovati odmah uredbom Vlade. Sveukupno gledano, prijedlog je ostvariv u okviru jednog vladajućeg mandata i usklađen je s postojećim obavezama u procesu pristupanja EU.

assessments.summary_mne: Pozicija Crne Gore kao najbolje rangiranje zemlje Zapadnog Balkana na Indeksu percepcije korupcije za 2025. godinu, sa skorom 46/100, pozitivan je signal za Ministarstvo finansija. Iako ovo samo po sebi nije vladina odluka, odražava institucionalne uslove koji direktno utiču na fiskalnu kredibilnost, troškove zaduživanja, privlačenje stranih direktnih investicija i izglede za pristupanje EU. Međutim, skor od 46 i dalje svrstava Crnu Goru ispod prosjeka EU i ukazuje na to da i dalje postoje značajni nedostaci u upravljanju, koji nastavljaju da nameću mjerljiv fiskalni trošak kroz više premije rizika i izgubljene investicije.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Vodeća pozicija Crne Gore na rang-listi IPC-a za Zapadni Balkan skroman je, ali značajan pozitivan signal za fiskalnu kredibilnost, povjerenje investitora i perspektivu pristupanja EU. Međutim, skor od 46/100 ostaje znatno ispod evropskih standarda, a Ministarstvo preporučuje da se ovaj relativni uspjeh iskoristi za sprovođenje konkretnih antikorupcijskih reformi u oblasti javnih nabavki i poreske administracije, kako bi se ostvarili opipljivi fiskalni dobici.
key_concerns_mne: Skor od 46/100 ostaje otprilike 18 poena ispod prosjeka EU, što ukazuje na značajan jaz u upravljanju koji utiče na fiskalnu kredibilnost i konvergenciju sa EU.
Skor stagnira umjesto da raste, što sugeriše da antikorupcijske reforme još uvijek nisu dale mjerljive rezultate koji bi prevazišli održavanje trenutnog stanja.
Neefikasnosti u javnim nabavkama povezane s korupcijom vjerovatno koštaju budžet desetine miliona eura godišnje, smanjujući efektivni uticaj programa kapitalnih investicija.
Persistentna siva ekonomija, povezana s niskim institucionalnim povjerenjem, nastavlja da erodira poresku osnovicu i ograničava fiskalni prostor bez mogućnosti povećanja poreskih stopa.
Crna Gora dijeli svoju rang-listu s državama koje nisu kandidati za EU, što narušava narativ o konvergenciji s evropskim standardima.
Indeksi percepcije mogu biti nestabilni i pod uticajem medijskih ciklusa; vlada ne bi trebalo da se oslanja na ovaj pokazatelj kao primarni indikator uspjeha reformi.
recommendations_mne: Naručiti nezavisnu procjenu fiskalnog uticaja korupcije na efikasnost javnih nabavki, naplatu poreza i povrate kapitalnih investicija, kako bi se kvantifikovala stvarna budžetska cijena trenutnog skora na IPC-u.

Ubrzati digitalizaciju poreske administracije i sistema javnih nabavki, uključujući obaveznu elektronsku nabavku za sve ugovore iznad 50.000 eura, kako bi se smanjilo diskreciono odlučivanje i poboljšala transparentnost.

Osnovati posebnu antikorupcijsku jedinicu u okviru Ministarstva finansija fokusiranu na curenje prihoda, nezakonite finansijske tokove i transparentnost stvarnog vlasništva, usklađenu sa zahtjevima Direktive EU o sprečavanju pranja novca.
Iskoristiti povoljnu regionalnu rang-listu kao marketinšku prednost u predstojećim emisijama euroobveznica i prezentacijama investitorima, kako bi se pregovarale niže marže na državni dug.
Postaviti konkretan cilj dostizanja skora na IPC-u od 50 do 2028. godine i 55 do 2030. godine, s povezanim prekretnicama u okviru pregovaračkog procesa pristupanja EU za Poglavlja 23 i 24.
Ojačati saradnju s Državnom revizorskom institucijom kako bi se osiguralo da se revizije izvršenja budžeta objavljuju blagovremeno i da se prate preporuke revizora radi njihove implementacije.

assessments.summary: Montenegro's top ranking in the Western Balkans on the 2025 Corruption Perceptions Index is a positive signal for the economy, particularly for foreign investor confidence and the country's EU accession narrative. However, a score of 46/100 remains below the EU average and indicates persistent systemic corruption challenges that continue to deter higher-quality FDI, increase transaction costs for businesses, and undermine fair competition. The stability of the score, while commendable in a worsening global environment, also suggests a plateau rather than genuine reform momentum.
assessments.executive_summary: Montenegro's best-in-region CPI ranking is a useful branding asset for attracting investment and supporting EU accession talks, but a score of 46/100 still signals significant corruption risks that raise business costs and deter quality FDI. The Ministry of Economy recommends translating this relative advantage into concrete anti-corruption reforms targeting public procurement, business licensing, and the informal economy to achieve measurable economic gains.
assessments.reasoning:
From an economic development perspective, corruption perception directly affects Montenegro's ability to attract and retain foreign direct investment. International investors routinely consult the CPI as part of due diligence, and Montenegro's position as the regional leader provides a competitive edge over Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Albania when investors are choosing among Western Balkan destinations. This is particularly relevant for sectors where Montenegro competes regionally, such as tourism infrastructure, energy, and real estate development.

However, the Ministry must be candid: 46 points out of 100 is not a strong score in absolute terms. It places Montenegro alongside Kuwait, Armenia, Namibia, and Senegal -- countries not typically associated with robust rule of law or ease of doing business. For comparison, the EU average hovers around 64 points, and EU candidate countries are expected to demonstrate convergence toward that standard. Montenegro remains 18 points below this benchmark, which is a material gap.

For the SME ecosystem, corruption manifests as uneven enforcement of regulations, opaque public procurement processes, and informal payments that disproportionately burden small firms lacking political connections. The World Bank's enterprise surveys for Montenegro have consistently shown that firms identify corruption and unfair competition as major constraints. A CPI score of 46 is consistent with these findings. Entrepreneurs in the northern and less developed regions are particularly affected, as local governance tends to be less transparent than in Podgorica.

Regarding the labor market, corruption correlates with informality. Montenegro's informal economy is estimated at 25-30 percent of GDP, and patronage-based hiring in the public sector distorts labor allocation. While the CPI ranking itself does not directly address these issues, it reflects the institutional environment that sustains them. Genuine anti-corruption progress would translate into more formal employment, better tax collection, and more efficient public spending on active labor market policies.

On energy and industrial policy, the corruption perception is relevant to the transparency of concession agreements, energy sector procurement, and regulatory decisions. Montenegro's coal phase-out, renewable energy auctions, and alignment with the Energy Community Treaty all require clean procurement and regulatory processes. Investors in capital-intensive energy projects are particularly sensitive to governance risks, given long payback periods.

The fact that the score remained stable at 46 while the global average declined is a modest positive, but the Ministry cautions against interpreting stagnation as success. Montenegro has been in the 44-47 range for several years, suggesting a structural ceiling that will not be breached without deeper institutional reforms in the judiciary, public procurement, and state-owned enterprise governance. The regional lead is partly a function of deterioration elsewhere, particularly Serbia's sharp decline, rather than Montenegro's own improvement.

For EU accession negotiations, particularly Chapters 23 and 24 on judiciary and fundamental rights, a stable CPI can support the narrative of incremental progress, but the European Commission's annual reports look beyond headline scores to specific reform benchmarks. The Ministry of Economy's interest is in ensuring that anti-corruption reforms have tangible economic outcomes: lower business costs, fairer competition, and higher-quality investment.
key_concerns: A score of 46/100 remains well below the EU average of approximately 64, signaling that Montenegro has significant ground to cover before meeting EU standards on governance and transparency.
Score stability over multiple years suggests a structural reform plateau rather than genuine improvement, which may eventually erode investor confidence if no upward trajectory materializes.
Corruption in public procurement continues to disadvantage SMEs and distort competition, particularly in construction, infrastructure, and energy sectors where government contracts are significant.
The informal economy, estimated at 25-30 percent of GDP, is both a cause and consequence of corruption, reducing the tax base and undermining formal businesses that comply with regulations.
Regional leadership is partly driven by deterioration in peer countries rather than Montenegro's own gains, making the ranking a fragile competitive advantage.
Transparency in energy sector concessions and renewable energy auctions remains a concern for attracting long-term capital-intensive investment.
recommendations: Actively use the CPI ranking in investment promotion campaigns led by MIPA (Montenegrin Investment Promotion Agency), while being transparent about the reform agenda needed to reach EU-level scores.

Establish a public procurement transparency portal with real-time data on government contracts, beneficial ownership of bidders, and contract performance, specifically targeting sectors critical to economic development.
Introduce a corruption impact assessment as part of all new economic legislation and regulatory changes, ensuring that rules do not inadvertently create rent-seeking opportunities.
Accelerate digitalization of business licensing and permit processes to reduce discretionary decision-making by public officials, particularly in construction, tourism, and energy project approvals.
Set a concrete CPI target of 52-55 points by 2030 as part of the national economic development strategy, with annual milestones tied to specific institutional reforms.
Prioritize anti-corruption reforms in the energy sector to build investor confidence ahead of planned renewable energy auctions and the coal phase-out timeline.

counter_proposal.title: From Ranking to Reform Dividends: An Economic Anti-Corruption Action Plan
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than treating the CPI ranking as a passive indicator, the Ministry of Economy would develop a targeted anti-corruption action plan focused on the economic sectors where corruption most directly impedes growth, investment, and employment. This would link governance reforms to measurable economic outcomes such as FDI inflows, SME creation rates, and informal economy reduction, creating accountability beyond the headline score.
key_changes: Create a joint Ministry of Economy and Anti-Corruption Agency task force focused on corruption risks in the top five economic sectors by GDP contribution (tourism, energy, construction, trade, ICT).
Mandate full beneficial ownership disclosure for all companies bidding on public contracts above 50,000 EUR, integrated into the public procurement e-system.

Launch a Business Integrity Pact program where companies voluntarily commit to anti-corruption standards in exchange for streamlined regulatory treatment and priority access to EU-funded support programs.
Develop a CPI-to-GDP diagnostic that quantifies the estimated economic cost of corruption in Montenegro and publishes annual updates, creating political incentives for reform.
Pilot a corruption-free zone initiative in one municipality in the north, with simplified digital business processes and independent oversight, as a model for nationwide rollout.
expected_benefits: Improved FDI quality and volume by reducing perceived governance risk, potentially increasing annual FDI inflows by 10-15 percent over a 3-5 year horizon.
Reduction in informal economy share by 3-5 percentage points through fairer regulatory enforcement, increasing the tax base.
Higher SME survival and growth rates due to reduced compliance costs and fairer access to public contracts.
Stronger EU accession negotiation position on economic governance chapters, accelerating the timeline for market integration benefits.
Demonstration effect for regional economic cooperation under the Western Balkans Common Market agenda.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The digitalization and transparency components build on existing e-government infrastructure and EU-funded programs. The beneficial ownership registry aligns with the EU Anti-Money Laundering Directive requirements Montenegro must adopt. The main constraint is political will, as entrenched interests benefit from opaque procurement and regulatory discretion. A phased approach starting with pilot municipalities and voluntary business integrity pacts can build momentum before requiring broader legislative changes.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Od Rangiranja do Dividendi Reformi: Ekonomski Akcioni Plan za Borbu Protiv Korupcije
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da se rang na CPI koristi kao pasivni pokazatelj, Ministarstvo ekonomije bi razvilo ciljani akcioni plan za borbu protiv korupcije, usmjeren na ekonomske sektore u kojima korupcija najneposrednije otežava rast, investicije i zapošljavanje. Time bi se reforme upravljanja povezale sa mjerljivim ekonomskim ishodima – poput priliva SDI, stope osnivanja MSP-ova i smanjenja sive ekonomije – stvarajući odgovornost koja prevazilazi sam zbiorni rezultat.
key_changes_mne: Osnivanje zajedničke radne grupe Ministarstva ekonomije i Agencije za sprečavanje korupcije, usmjerene na koruptivne rizike u pet vodećih ekonomskih sektora po doprinosu BDP-u (turizam, energetika, građevinarstvo, trgovina, IKT).
Uvođenje obaveznog otkrivanja stvarnih vlasnika za sva preduzeća koja učestvuju na javnim tenderima iznad 50.000 EUR, integrisanog u elektronski sistem javnih nabavki.

Pokretanje programa Pakta o poslovnom integritetu, u okviru kojeg preduzeća dobrovoljno preuzimaju obaveze poštovanja antikorupcijskih standarda u zamjenu za olakšan regulatorni tretman i prioritetan pristup programima podrške finansiranim od strane EU.
Izrada CPI-BDP dijagnostike koja kvantifikuje procijenjene ekonomske troškove korupcije u Crnoj Gori i objavljuje godišnja ažuriranja, stvarajući time političke poticaje za sprovođenje reformi.
Pilotiranje inicijative zone bez korupcije u jednoj opštini na sjeveru, uz pojednostavjene digitalne poslovne procese i nezavisni nadzor, kao model za primjenu na nacionalnom nivou.
expected_benefits_mne: Poboljšanje kvaliteta i obima SDI smanjenjem percipiranog rizika u oblasti upravljanja, s potencijalnim povećanjem godišnjeg priliva SDI za 10–15 posto u periodu od 3 do 5 godina.
Smanjenje udjela sive ekonomije za 3 do 5 procentnih poena kroz pravednije regulatorno sprovođenje, čime se proširuje poreska osnovica.
Veće stope opstanka i rasta MSP-ova zahvaljujući smanjenim troškovima usklađenosti i pravičnijem pristupu javnim nabavkama.
Jača pregovaračka pozicija u procesu pristupanja EU u pogledu poglavlja o ekonomskom upravljanju, čime se ubrzava ostvarivanje koristi od integracije na tržištu.
Demonstracioni efekat za regionalnu ekonomsku saradnju u okviru agende Zajedničkog tržišta Zapadnog Balkana.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno izvodljivo. Komponente digitalizacije i transparentnosti nadovezuju se na postojeću e-upravu i programe finansirane od strane EU. Registar stvarnih vlasnika usklađen je sa zahtjevima Direktive EU o sprečavanju pranja novca koje Crna Gora mora da usvoji. Glavno ograničenje je politička volja, s obzirom na to da ukorijenjeni interesi imaju koristi od netransparentnih nabavki i regulatornog diskrecionog prava. Fazni pristup koji počinje s pilot-opštinama i dobrovoljnim paktovima o poslovnom integritetu može izgraditi zamah prije nego što se pristupi širim zakonodavnim promjenama.

assessments.summary_mne: Vodeća pozicija Crne Gore u Zapadnom Balkanu na Indeksu percepcije korupcije za 2025. godinu predstavlja pozitivan signal za ekonomiju, posebno u pogledu povjerenja stranih investitora i narativa o pristupanju EU. Međutim, rezultat od 46/100 i dalje je ispod prosjeka EU i ukazuje na sistemske izazove korupcije koji i dalje odvraćaju kvalitetnija strana direktna ulaganja, povećavaju transakcione troškove za preduzeća i narušavaju poštenu konkurenciju. Stabilnost rezultata, premda pohvalna u globalnom okruženju koje se pogoršava, ukazuje i na dostizanje platoa umjesto na stvarni zamah reformi.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Vodeći rang Crne Gore u regionu na CPI-ju predstavlja koristan brending adut za privlačenje ulaganja i podršku pregovorima o pristupanju EU, ali rezultat od 46/100 i dalje signalizira značajne korupcijske rizike koji povećavaju poslovne troškove i odvraćaju kvalitetna strana direktna ulaganja. Ministarstvo ekonomije preporučuje da se ova relativna prednost pretvori u konkretne antikorupcijske reforme usmjerene na javne nabavke, izdavanje poslovnih dozvola i neformalnu ekonomiju, s ciljem ostvarivanja mjerljivih ekonomskih rezultata.
key_concerns_mne: Rezultat od 46/100 znatno je ispod prosjeka EU od oko 64, što signalizira da Crna Gora ima još mnogo posla prije nego što dostigne standarde EU u oblasti upravljanja i transparentnosti.

Stabilnost rezultata tokom više godina ukazuje na strukturni plato reformi umjesto na stvarni napredak, što bi u konačnici moglo narušiti povjerenje investitora ukoliko se ne materijalizuje uzlazna putanja.

Korupcija u javnim nabavkama i dalje stavlja MSP u nepovoljan položaj i narušava konkurenciju, posebno u sektorima građevinarstva, infrastrukture i energetike, gdje su državni ugovori od velikog značaja.
Neformalna ekonomija, procijenjena na 25–30 posto BDP-a, istovremeno je i uzrok i posljedica korupcije, smanjuje poresku osnovu i nanosi štetu formalnim preduzećima koja poštuju propise.
Regionalno liderstvo dijelom je posljedica pogoršanja stanja u susjednim zemljama, a ne napretka same Crne Gore, što čini ovaj rang krhkom konkurentskom prednošću.
Transparentnost u dodjeli koncesija u energetskom sektoru i aukcijama obnovljivih izvora energije i dalje izaziva zabrinutost kada je riječ o privlačenju dugoročnih kapitalno intenzivnih ulaganja.
recommendations_mne: Aktivno koristiti rang na CPI u kampanjama za promociju ulaganja koje vodi MIPA (Agencija za promociju stranih ulaganja Crne Gore), uz transparentnost u pogledu agende reformi neophodnih za dostizanje rezultata na nivou EU.

Uspostaviti portal za transparentnost javnih nabavki s podacima u realnom vremenu o državnim ugovorima, stvarnom vlasništvu ponuđača i realizaciji ugovora, s posebnim fokusom na sektore ključne za ekonomski razvoj.
Uvesti procjenu uticaja korupcije u okviru svih novih ekonomskih zakona i regulatornih izmjena, kako bi se osiguralo da propisi nenamjerno ne stvaraju mogućnosti za iznuđivanje renti.

Ubrzati digitalizaciju procesa izdavanja poslovnih dozvola i odobrenja radi smanjenja diskrecijskog odlučivanja javnih službenika, posebno u oblasti građevinarstva, turizma i odobravanja energetskih projekata.
Postaviti konkretan cilj od 52–55 bodova na CPI do 2030. godine u okviru nacionalne strategije ekonomskog razvoja, uz godišnje rokove vezane za specifične institucionalne reforme.

Prioritizovati antikorupcijske reforme u energetskom sektoru kako bi se izgradilo povjerenje investitora uoči planiranih aukcija obnovljivih izvora energije i vremenskog okvira za postupno napuštanje uglja.

assessments.summary: Montenegro's position as the best-ranked Western Balkan country on the Corruption Perceptions Index is a meaningful signal for the tourism sector, particularly for attracting quality foreign investment, reinforcing destination credibility among EU source markets, and supporting the EU accession narrative that underpins tourism development strategy. However, a score of 46/100 remains mediocre in absolute terms and continues to reflect systemic governance weaknesses that directly harm tourism through opaque coastal construction permitting, unregulated short-term rentals, and inconsistent enforcement of environmental and labour standards in the hospitality sector.
assessments.executive_summary: The CPI ranking is a net positive for tourism brand positioning and investor confidence, but the score of 46/100 still signals governance gaps that directly undermine sustainable tourism development. The Ministry recommends leveraging this ranking in destination marketing while using it as a baseline to pursue transparency reforms specifically targeting coastal construction permits, concession contracts, and seasonal labour enforcement.
assessments.reasoning:
Tourism is Montenegro's most internationally exposed economic sector, generating approximately 40% of GDP either directly or indirectly. Perception of corruption matters enormously in this sector for three interconnected reasons: investor confidence, visitor trust, and EU alignment.

First, regarding investor confidence, Montenegro's coastal tourism infrastructure depends heavily on foreign direct investment, from Porto Montenegro in Tivat to ongoing hotel developments along the Budva Riviera. International hospitality chains and institutional investors use governance indicators, including the CPI, as part of their due diligence. Being the best-ranked country in the Western Balkans, and sitting above the global average, provides a marginal but real competitive advantage over Albania and Serbia when attracting hotel operators and tourism infrastructure developers. The gap with Croatia (only 2 points, 1 point behind) is also notable: it suggests Montenegro can credibly position itself as a governance peer to an EU member state in this specific metric.

Second, regarding visitor trust and destination reputation, modern tourists, particularly from high-spending Northern and Western European markets, are increasingly sensitive to governance quality. Overtourism debates in Dubrovnik and concerns about unregulated development in Albania create openings for Montenegro to market itself as a more responsibly governed destination. The CPI score, while modest, supports this narrative. It is particularly useful for Kotor Bay, where UNESCO World Heritage status creates heightened scrutiny of governance and planning integrity.

Third, regarding EU accession, Chapters 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) and 24 (Justice, Freedom and Security) of the EU acquis are directly linked to anti-corruption performance. Progress on these chapters signals to the EU tourism regulatory ecosystem that Montenegro is moving toward compliance with European standards on consumer protection, environmental regulation, and labour rights in the hospitality sector. This matters for integration into EU tourism quality frameworks and potential access to EU structural funds for sustainable tourism development.

However, the Ministry must be candid about the limitations. A score of 46/100 means Montenegro is still perceived as having significant corruption problems. In tourism-specific terms, this manifests in several well-documented ways: opaque issuance of coastal construction permits that enable overdevelopment in places like Becici and Rafailovici; non-transparent concession processes for beach management that generate public frustration and media coverage harmful to destination image; weak enforcement of labour regulations in seasonal hospitality employment, where informal arrangements and wage theft remain common; inconsistent application of environmental standards in national park buffer zones and along the coast; and a short-term rental market that operates largely outside regulatory oversight, distorting housing markets in Budva, Kotor, and Herceg Novi while creating unfair competition for licensed accommodation providers.

The ranking is therefore best understood as a floor rather than a ceiling. It provides useful marketing material and a credible regional comparison, but it must not be used to justify complacency about the governance failures that most directly affect tourism quality and sustainability.
key_concerns: A score of 46/100 remains below the EU average of approximately 64 points, meaning Montenegro's governance perception still lags behind the standards expected for EU-aligned tourism regulation and consumer protection.

Coastal construction permitting remains one of the most corruption-prone areas of Montenegrin governance, directly threatening the scenic and environmental assets that underpin tourism value, particularly along the Budva Riviera and Lustica Peninsula.
Beach concession allocation processes lack transparency, generating recurring public controversy that damages destination reputation during the peak season media cycle.

Seasonal hospitality workers remain vulnerable to informal employment arrangements and weak enforcement of labour standards, which conflicts with EU social tourism frameworks and undermines service quality.

The short-term rental sector operates with minimal regulatory oversight, creating tax leakage, housing market distortion in key tourism municipalities, and unfair competition for licensed hotels and guesthouses.

There is a risk that the government uses this ranking for self-congratulatory messaging without pursuing the sector-specific transparency reforms that would translate improved perception into improved tourism governance outcomes.
recommendations: Incorporate the CPI ranking into Montenegro's destination marketing strategy for 2026, particularly in materials targeting Northern European and institutional investor audiences, framing Montenegro as the governance leader in the Western Balkans.

Establish a publicly accessible digital registry of all coastal construction permits and beach concession contracts, with clear documentation of decision-making criteria and awarded parties, to directly address the most tourism-relevant corruption risks.

Introduce mandatory digital registration and tax compliance for all short-term rental properties listed on platforms such as Airbnb and Booking.com, following the model of Croatia's eVisitor system, which has successfully brought informal rentals into the regulatory framework.

Strengthen labour inspection capacity during the May-October peak season, with dedicated teams for hospitality and tourism employers, to ensure seasonal workers receive legally mandated contracts, wages, and social insurance contributions.

Use the CPI ranking as a baseline metric in the National Tourism Development Strategy, setting a target of 50 or above by 2028, with annual reporting on tourism-specific governance indicators such as permit transparency, concession fairness, and environmental enforcement.

Coordinate with the Ministry of Justice and the Anti-Corruption Agency to ensure that tourism-sector governance improvements are documented and submitted as evidence in EU accession Chapters 23 and 24 progress reports.

counter_proposal.title: Tourism Governance Transparency Initiative
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than treating the CPI ranking as a passive reputational asset, the Ministry of Tourism would launch a targeted Tourism Governance Transparency Initiative that converts the ranking into concrete sector-specific reforms. This initiative would create open data platforms for coastal permits and concessions, digitize short-term rental registration, and establish a tourism-specific anti-corruption action plan aligned with EU accession benchmarks.
key_changes: Create an open-access digital portal publishing all coastal construction permits, spatial plans, and beach concession awards in real time, modeled on Croatia's e-Dozvola system.

Mandate platform-based short-term rental registration through a national eVisitor-style system, requiring all listings on Airbnb, Booking.com, and similar platforms to display a valid registration number.

Establish a Tourism Integrity Unit within the Ministry, staffed with 3-5 specialists, to monitor corruption risks in permitting, concessions, and public procurement for tourism infrastructure projects.

Publish an annual Tourism Governance Report Card with measurable indicators on permit transparency, labour law compliance, environmental enforcement, and concession fairness, benchmarked against EU member state standards.

Partner with Transparency International's Montenegro chapter to conduct annual perception surveys specifically targeting tourism sector stakeholders including hoteliers, seasonal workers, tour operators, and municipal tourism offices.
expected_benefits: Improved investor confidence through demonstrable governance transparency in the most investment-relevant areas of tourism regulation.
Stronger destination brand positioning in high-value European source markets where governance perception influences travel decisions.
Accelerated EU accession progress by generating concrete evidence of sectoral anti-corruption reform for Chapters 23 and 24.
Reduced informal economy in tourism through digital rental registration, increasing tax revenue and leveling the competitive playing field for licensed accommodation.
Better seasonal labour conditions through systematic inspection and enforcement, improving service quality and reducing reputational risk from worker exploitation stories.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility for the digital transparency and registration components, which can build on existing e-government infrastructure and follow proven regional models such as Croatia's eVisitor and e-Dozvola systems. The Tourism Integrity Unit requires modest budgetary allocation and could be operational within 12 months. The annual governance report card is low-cost and can leverage existing data collection. Political will is the primary constraint, but the CPI ranking itself provides useful political cover for reform.
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da se CPI rang tretira kao pasivna reputacijska vrijednost, Ministarstvo turizma bi pokrenulo ciljanu Inicijativu za transparentnost upravljanja turizmom koja taj rang pretvara u konkretne reformske mjere specifične za sektor. Ova inicijativa bi stvorila otvorene platforme podataka za priobalne dozvole i koncesije, digitalizovala registraciju kratkoročnog iznajmljivanja i uspostavila akcioni plan za borbu protiv korupcije u turizmu, usklađen sa mjerilima za pristupanje EU.
key_changes_mne: Kreirati digitalni portal otvorenog pristupa koji u realnom vremenu objavljuje sve građevinske dozvole na primorju, prostorne planove i dodjele koncesija za plaže, po uzoru na hrvatski sistem e-Dozvola.

Uvesti obaveznu registraciju kratkoročnog iznajmljivanja putem platformi kroz nacionalni sistem sličan eVisitoru, koji zahtijeva da svi oglasi na Airbnb-u, Booking.com-u i sličnim platformama prikazuju važeći registracioni broj.

Bolji uslovi za sezonske radnike kroz sistemske inspekcije i sprovođenje propisa, što unapređuje kvalitet usluga i smanjuje reputacijski rizik od priča o eksploataciji radnika.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost za komponente digitalne transparentnosti i registracije, koje mogu da se nadovežu na postojeću e-upravu i slijede provjerene regionalne modele poput hrvatskih sistema eVisitor i e-Dozvola. Jedinica za integritet u turizmu zahtijeva skromna budžetska sredstva i mogla bi biti operativna u roku od 12 mjeseci. Politička volja je ključno ograničenje, ali sam CPI rang pruža koristan politički okvir za sprovođenje reformi.

assessments.summary_mne: Pozicija Crne Gore kao najrangiranije zemlje Zapadnog Balkana na Indeksu percepcije korupcije predstavlja značajan signal za turistički sektor, posebno u pogledu privlačenja kvalitetnih stranih investicija, jačanja kredibiliteta destinacije na tržištima EU, te podupiranja narativa o pristupanju EU koji čini osnovu strategije razvoja turizma. Međutim, rezultat od 46/100 ostaje osrednji u apsolutnom smislu i i dalje odražava sistemske slabosti u upravljanju koje direktno štete turizmu kroz netransparentno izdavanje građevinskih dozvola na primorju, neregulisano kratkoročno iznajmljivanje i nedosljedno sprovođenje ekoloških i radnih standarda u ugostiteljskom sektoru.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Rangiranje na Indeksu percepcije korupcije predstavlja neto pozitivan signal za pozicioniranje turističkog brenda i povjerenje investitora, ali rezultat od 46/100 i dalje ukazuje na nedostatke u upravljanju koji direktno podrivaju održivi razvoj turizma. Ministarstvo preporučuje korišćenje ovog rangiranja u destinacijskom marketingu, uz istovremenu upotrebu kao polazne osnove za provođenje reformi transparentnosti koje posebno ciljaju građevinske dozvole na primorju, koncesijske ugovore i sprovođenje radnih prava sezonskih radnika.
key_concerns_mne: Rezultat od 46/100 ostaje ispod prosjeka EU od otprilike 64 poena, što znači da percepcija upravljanja u Crnoj Gori i dalje zaostaje za standardima koji se očekuju u okviru turističke regulative i zaštite potrošača usklađenih sa EU.

Izdavanje građevinskih dozvola na primorju ostaje jedna od oblasti crnogorskog upravljanja najizloženijih korupciji, direktno ugrožavajući prirodne i ekološke vrijednosti na kojima počiva turistička atraktivnost, posebno duž Budvanske rivijere i Luštičkog poluostrva.
Postupci dodjele koncesija za plaže nedostaju transparentnosti, što izaziva ponavljajuće javne kontroverze koje narušavaju reputaciju destinacije tokom medijskog ciklusa glavne sezone.

Sezonski radnici u ugostiteljstvu ostaju ranjivi zbog neformalnih radnih aranžmana i slabog sprovođenja radnih standarda, što je u suprotnosti sa evropskim okvirima socijalnog turizma i umanjuje kvalitet usluge.

Sektor kratkoročnog iznajmljivanja funkcioniše uz minimalan regulatorni nadzor, što uzrokuje poreske gubitke, deformaciju tržišta nekretnina u ključnim turističkim opštinama i neravnopravnu konkurenciju licenciranim hotelima i pansionima.

Postoji rizik da Vlada koristi ovo rangiranje za samohvalisavu komunikaciju bez sprovođenja reformi transparentnosti specifičnih za sektor, koje bi poboljšanu percepciju pretvorile u konkretno unapređenje upravljanja turizmom.
recommendations_mne: Uključiti rangiranje na Indeksu percepcije korupcije u strategiju destinacijskog marketinga Crne Gore za 2026. godinu, posebno u materijale namijenjene sjevernoevropskoj publici i institucionalnim investitorima, pozicionirajući Crnu Goru kao lidera u upravljanju na Zapadnom Balkanu.

Uspostaviti javno dostupan digitalni registar svih građevinskih dozvola na primorju i ugovora o koncesiji plaža, s jasnom dokumentacijom kriterijuma odlučivanja i dodijeljenih ugovora, kako bi se direktno odgovorilo na najrelevantnije korupcijske rizike u turizmu.

Uvesti obaveznu digitalnu registraciju i poresku usklađenost za sve objekte za kratkoročni najam objavljene na platformama kao što su Airbnb i Booking.com, prema uzoru na hrvatski sistem eVisitor, koji je uspješno integrisao neformalne iznajmljivače u regulatorni okvir.

Ojačati kapacitete inspekcije rada tokom glavne sezone od maja do oktobra, uz namjenske timove za ugostiteljske i turističke poslodavce, kako bi se osiguralo da sezonski radnici dobijaju zakonski propisane ugovore, zarade i doprinose za socijalno osiguranje.

Koristiti rangiranje na Indeksu percepcije korupcije kao polaznu mjeru u Nacionalnoj strategiji razvoja turizma, postavljajući cilj od 50 ili više poena do 2028. godine, uz godišnje izvještavanje o pokazateljima upravljanja specifičnim za turizam, kao što su transparentnost dozvola, pravednost koncesija i sprovođenje ekoloških propisa.

Koordinirati s Ministarstvom pravde i Agencijom za sprječavanje korupcije kako bi se unapređenja upravljanja u turističkom sektoru dokumentovala i dostavila kao dokaz u izvještajima o napretku u okviru poglavlja 23 i 24 pristupnih pregovora sa EU.

debate.consensus_summary: All ten ministries agree that Montenegro's 65th place ranking on the 2025 Corruption Perceptions Index with a score of 46 out of 100, while representing the best result in the Western Balkans, is insufficient for a country pursuing EU membership. There is unanimous agreement on the following points: (1) A score of 46 remains well below the EU average of approximately 64, meaning Montenegro has an 18-point gap to close before it can credibly claim to meet European governance standards; (2) The result must not be used as grounds for political self-congratulation or complacency, as relative regional leadership does not constitute absolute adequacy; (3) The CPI is a perception-based index drawing on expert and business surveys, not a direct measure of enforcement outcomes, conviction rates, or institutional capacity, meaning the score may overstate or understate actual corruption conditions depending on the sector; (4) Multiple sector-specific corruption risks persist that the aggregate CPI score does not capture, including informal payments in healthcare, patronage-based hiring in education, integrity deficits in policing, opaque procurement in coastal construction, and environmental permitting irregularities; (5) All ministries recommend establishing concrete improvement targets in the range of CPI 50 to 55 by 2028 to 2030 as a measurable commitment to anti-corruption progress; and (6) The European Commission will evaluate Montenegro not on regional comparisons but on absolute progress toward EU benchmarks, and year-on-year stagnation or marginal improvement will be noted critically in annual progress reports. The weighted average score across all ministries is 6.1 out of 10, reflecting a cautiously positive but heavily qualified assessment.
disagreements: Degree of optimism: The Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Tourism assign the highest scores (7 out of 10), viewing the ranking as having tangible value for investor confidence and destination marketing respectively. In contrast, the Ministry of Environment and Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare assign neutral scores (5 out of 10), arguing that the aggregate CPI figure obscures persistent sector-specific corruption that directly undermines their policy domains. This four-ministry spread reflects a fundamental tension between macro-level signaling value and micro-level lived reality.

Relevance to EU accession benchmarks: The Ministry of EU Integration emphasizes that the European Commission does not use CPI rankings as formal benchmarks for Chapter 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) but will note year-on-year stagnation as an indicator of reform momentum. The Ministry of Justice counters that the more relevant metric is the gap between legislative frameworks and actual enforcement outcomes, particularly the persistent lack of final convictions in high-level corruption cases. The Ministry of Interior adds that Montenegro shares its CPI tier with countries that are not EU candidates, suggesting the ranking positions Montenegro in company that undermines its frontrunner narrative.

Whether the result validates current anti-corruption strategy: The Ministry of Finance and the ruling coalition perspective treat the ranking as partial validation of governance reforms implemented since 2020. The Ministry of Justice and opposition-aligned analysis argue that maintaining a score of 46 for several consecutive years indicates stagnation rather than progress, and that legislative adoption without enforcement track records is insufficient. The question of whether 46 represents a plateau or a base for improvement remains unresolved.

Sector-specific blind spots of the CPI methodology: The Ministry of Health notes that informal payments to medical professionals, a widespread corruption form affecting ordinary citizens, are poorly captured by expert perception surveys. The Ministry of Education flags that nepotistic hiring practices in schools and universities operate below the threshold of international observer attention. The Ministry of Environment argues that corruption in spatial planning and coastal construction permits represents some of Montenegro's most economically damaging corruption but is invisible in aggregate indices. These sectoral critiques challenge whether the CPI score should be treated as a meaningful governance indicator at all.

Marketing and communication strategy: The Ministry of Tourism sees an opportunity to leverage the best-in-Western-Balkans positioning in destination branding and investor attraction campaigns. The Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare cautions that promoting the ranking while citizens experience corruption in daily interactions with public services risks deepening the gap between official narratives and public trust. The Ministry of EU Integration warns that premature celebration could irritate European Commission evaluators who expect self-critical assessment rather than self-promotion.
