PARLIAMENTARY DEBATE TRANSCRIPT
Skupstina Crne Gore -- Plenary Session
Subject: Montenegro's Ranking on the Transparency International Corruption Perceptions Index 2025
Date: February 2026


I. OPENING -- FRAMING THE DISCUSSION

This session convenes to examine the assessments of ten government ministries regarding Montenegro's placement on the 2025 Corruption Perceptions Index published by Transparency International. The facts are as follows: Montenegro ranks 65th globally with a score of 46 out of 100, representing the highest score among Western Balkan countries. The EU average stands at approximately 64 out of 100. Montenegro's score represents continuity rather than dramatic change from recent years.

The Parliament has received assessments from the following ministries: Finance (7 out of 10, positive), Tourism (7 out of 10, positive), Justice (6 out of 10, positive), Interior (6 out of 10, positive), Education (6 out of 10, positive), EU Integration (6 out of 10, positive), Economy (6 out of 10, positive), Health (6 out of 10, positive), Environment (5 out of 10, neutral), and Labour and Social Welfare (5 out of 10, neutral). The weighted average is 6.1 out of 10. No ministry assessed the result as negative, but no ministry rated it above 7 either. This narrow band of cautious positivity itself tells a story: this is a result that is better than bad but far from good.


II. MINISTRY POSITIONS -- THE OPTIMISTIC WING

The Ministry of Finance delivers the most positive framing, scoring the result at 7 out of 10. The Ministry argues that for a small, open economy dependent on foreign direct investment and access to international capital markets, the CPI ranking carries material economic weight. Institutional investors, sovereign wealth funds, and credit rating agencies reference CPI scores as governance proxies when making allocation decisions. Montenegro's position as the regional leader in the Western Balkans provides a competitive advantage in attracting capital that might otherwise flow to Serbia, North Macedonia, or Albania. The Ministry notes that every point improvement on the CPI correlates with measurable improvements in borrowing costs and investment attractiveness. However, the Ministry of Finance is careful to note that 46 out of 100 still places Montenegro in the lower third of all assessed countries globally, and that the 18-point gap to the EU average represents a structural impediment to Montenegro's economic convergence aspirations.

The Ministry of Tourism shares the 7 out of 10 score and offers a complementary argument. In the competitive Mediterranean and Adriatic tourism market, destination perception matters enormously. Tour operators and cruise lines assess political stability and governance quality when making routing decisions. Montenegro's position as the least corrupt Western Balkan country provides marketing leverage that the National Tourism Organisation can deploy in key source markets across Western Europe. The Ministry argues that the ranking supports the premium tourism positioning strategy, differentiating Montenegro from regional competitors. At the same time, the Ministry acknowledges that tourism-sector corruption, particularly in coastal construction permitting, marina concessions, and hospitality licensing, remains a significant reputational risk that could undermine the very narrative the CPI ranking supports.

The Ministry of Economy aligns with Finance and Tourism on the investment signaling value but broadens the analysis to the business environment. The Ministry argues that the CPI ranking, combined with ongoing improvements in the World Bank's business climate indicators, creates a composite picture that supports Montenegro's pitch to foreign investors. The Ministry is particularly focused on the technology and services sectors, where governance perceptions directly affect location decisions by companies evaluating the Western Balkans for nearshoring operations.


III. MINISTRY POSITIONS -- THE CAUTIOUS CENTER

Six ministries score the result at 6 out of 10, reflecting a carefully qualified positive assessment that emphasizes risks and gaps as much as the headline figure.

The Ministry of Justice provides the most analytically rigorous assessment in this group. The Ministry's core argument is that the CPI measures perceptions, not outcomes. Montenegro has made substantial progress in adopting anti-corruption legislation, establishing institutional frameworks including the Anti-Corruption Agency and the Special State Prosecutor's Office, and aligning its legal architecture with EU standards. However, the Ministry identifies what it calls the enforcement gap: the persistent disconnect between legislative frameworks and actual judicial outcomes. Montenegro continues to lack a track record of final convictions in high-level corruption cases involving senior officials, politically connected business figures, or organized crime networks operating through legitimate institutions. The Ministry argues that until the judiciary delivers convictions that withstand appellate review in cases involving public officials of genuine political significance, the CPI score reflects legislative intent rather than operational reality. The Ministry recommends that Montenegro set not only a CPI target of 50 to 55 by 2028 but also establish quantitative enforcement benchmarks: a minimum number of high-level corruption indictments, prosecutions, and convictions per year, publicly tracked and reported.

The Ministry of Interior adds a dimension that other ministries largely overlook. The Ministry notes that Montenegro's CPI tier includes countries that are not EU candidates and in some cases are not even aspiring to European integration. This company of peers undermines the narrative of Montenegro as a governance frontrunner. The Ministry further notes that police integrity remains an area of concern, with the European Commission's progress reports consistently identifying politicization of police appointments, insufficient internal affairs capacity, and inadequate whistleblower protection for law enforcement officers who report corruption within the force. The Ministry argues that a CPI score of 46 is consistent with a country that has the institutional architecture of an anti-corruption state but not yet the operational culture of one.

The Ministry of EU Integration delivers perhaps the most strategically important assessment. The Ministry warns that the European Commission does not use CPI rankings as formal benchmarks in accession negotiations, but Commission staff and European Parliament rapporteurs reference them in annual progress reports and political assessments. The Ministry's central concern is that year-on-year stagnation at or around 46 will be interpreted in Brussels not as stability but as a lack of reform momentum. The Commission evaluates trends, not snapshots. A country that improves from 40 to 46 over several years receives credit for trajectory; a country that remains at 46 for consecutive years faces questions about whether reform has plateaued. The Ministry further warns that Montenegro cannot afford to present this result as an achievement in Brussels. The Commission expects candidate countries to demonstrate self-critical assessment capacity, and any government communication that frames 46 out of 100 as a success will be noted unfavorably.

The Ministry of Education identifies corruption risks specific to its domain that the CPI aggregate obscures. Nepotistic hiring practices in schools and universities, where appointments are influenced by political party affiliation or family connections rather than professional qualifications, represent a form of corruption that directly undermines educational quality and contributes to brain drain among young academics. The Ministry notes that students and young professionals who witness institutionalized favoritism in educational institutions draw conclusions about the broader society and frequently choose to emigrate. The Ministry recommends that anti-corruption efforts specifically target education sector procurement and hiring through transparent, merit-based appointment processes.

The Ministry of Health raises the issue of informal payments, one of the most pervasive and socially corrosive forms of corruption in Montenegro. Patients making informal cash payments to doctors, nurses, and hospital staff to secure timely treatment, specialist referrals, or simply adequate attention represents corruption that affects ordinary citizens in their most vulnerable moments. The Ministry argues that this form of corruption is poorly captured by the CPI methodology, which relies on expert and business surveys rather than citizen experience surveys. A CPI score of 46 tells Brussels nothing about whether a cancer patient in Podgorica must pay an envelope to a surgeon before receiving treatment. The Ministry recommends complementing CPI monitoring with citizen experience surveys and healthcare-specific integrity assessments.


IV. MINISTRY POSITIONS -- THE CAUTIOUS WING

The Ministry of Environment and the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare assign neutral scores of 5 out of 10, reflecting the most skeptical assessments in the group.

The Ministry of Environment argues that corruption in spatial planning, construction permitting, and environmental impact assessment processes represents some of Montenegro's most economically and environmentally damaging corruption, yet it is largely invisible in aggregate perception indices. The Ministry points to the Adriatic coastline, where illegal or semi-legal construction in protected zones, facilitated by corrupt permitting processes, threatens both environmental assets and long-term tourism revenue. The Ministry notes that environmental enforcement capacity remains severely limited, with insufficient inspectors, inadequate penalties, and political interference in enforcement decisions. The Ministry's position is that until sector-specific corruption in environmental governance is measurably reduced, the aggregate CPI score provides false comfort.

The Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare focuses on the distributional dimension. The Ministry argues that corruption disproportionately affects vulnerable populations: workers in the informal economy who cannot access labor protections, social welfare recipients who face bureaucratic gatekeeping, and minority communities whose access to public services is mediated by patronage networks. The Ministry notes that the CPI's expert-survey methodology tends to capture perceptions of grand corruption and business-environment corruption while underweighting the everyday petty corruption that shapes the lives of ordinary citizens, particularly those in economically precarious positions. The Ministry recommends that Montenegro develop and publish a supplementary corruption impact assessment focusing specifically on how corruption affects social welfare delivery, labor rights enforcement, and access to public services for disadvantaged populations.


V. PARTY BLOC REACTIONS -- RULING COALITION

The Europe Now! and URA coalition, holding the parliamentary majority, frames the CPI result as evidence of the governance trajectory established since the coalition took power. The ruling coalition argues that Montenegro's position as the Western Balkans leader on corruption perceptions reflects the cumulative impact of institutional reforms, including strengthening the Anti-Corruption Agency's independence, increasing transparency in public procurement, and pursuing digitalization of government services to reduce opportunities for corrupt intermediation. The coalition points to the improvement from Montenegro's historical CPI scores as evidence of directional progress and argues that the reform path established under their governance is producing measurable results recognized by international observers.

However, the ruling coalition is careful to avoid triumphalism, recognizing that a score of 46 remains far below EU standards. The coalition argues that anti-corruption reform is inherently generational in nature and that expecting rapid CPI improvements in a small post-Yugoslav state still undergoing democratic consolidation is unrealistic. The coalition commits to a target of CPI 52 to 55 by 2028 and emphasizes that the government's anti-corruption strategy is focused on systemic institutional change rather than headline-grabbing prosecutions that may not withstand judicial review.

The URA component of the coalition specifically echoes the Ministry of Environment's concerns about sector-specific corruption in construction and spatial planning, noting that URA has consistently advocated for stronger environmental enforcement and transparent coastal development permitting. URA argues that the coalition's environmental governance reforms, while slower than desired, are addressing the very issues the Ministry of Environment identifies.


VI. PARTY BLOC REACTIONS -- DPS AND SDP OPPOSITION

The DPS-led opposition, comprising the largest opposition force in Parliament, delivers a sharp challenge to the ruling coalition's framing. The opposition's central argument is that a CPI score of 46, essentially unchanged from recent years, represents stagnation rather than progress. The opposition notes that the ruling coalition came to power on an explicit anti-corruption platform, promising transformational change in governance standards. Several years later, Montenegro remains in the lower third of all countries globally, with a score that would place it among the worst performers in the EU if it were a member state.

The DPS bloc focuses particularly on the enforcement gap identified by the Ministry of Justice. The opposition argues that the ruling coalition has been more effective at adopting legislation than at securing convictions. The opposition points to the continued absence of final convictions in major corruption cases involving current or former senior officials as evidence that the anti-corruption framework remains more decorative than operational. The opposition further argues that selective prosecution, targeting political opponents rather than systematically pursuing corruption across the political spectrum, undermines both the CPI score and public trust.

The SDP component of the opposition adds a social dimension, echoing the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare's concerns about corruption's disproportionate impact on vulnerable populations. The SDP argues that the ruling coalition's focus on macro-level governance indicators comes at the expense of addressing the everyday corruption that ordinary citizens experience in healthcare, education, and social services. The SDP notes that for a pensioner forced to pay informally for medical treatment or a young graduate whose job prospects depend on party connections rather than qualifications, Montenegro's regional CPI leadership is meaningless.

The opposition collectively calls for the establishment of an independent anti-corruption monitoring mechanism outside government control, publication of annual enforcement statistics including indictment and conviction rates for public corruption cases, and a parliamentary inquiry into why the Special State Prosecutor's Office has failed to secure high-level corruption convictions despite the institutional resources and legal tools available to it.


VII. PARTY BLOC REACTIONS -- DF AND DNP BLOC

The Democratic Front and Democratic People's Party bloc brings a fundamentally different analytical framework to the discussion. The DF and DNP question the methodological validity and political neutrality of the Corruption Perceptions Index itself. The bloc argues that the CPI is compiled by a Western-based organization using surveys of Western-aligned experts and business executives, producing an index that inherently favors countries aligned with Western institutional norms and penalizes countries with different governance traditions.

The DF and DNP bloc argues that Montenegro's obsession with Western governance metrics is itself a form of institutional capture, subordinating national sovereignty and policy autonomy to the benchmarks and evaluations of external organizations. The bloc questions whether the EU's average CPI score of approximately 64 reflects genuinely lower corruption in EU member states or merely different forms of corruption that the methodology does not capture, such as corporate regulatory capture, revolving-door corruption between government and industry, and the role of lobbying as legalized influence-peddling.

The bloc further argues that the ruling coalition's and opposition's shared focus on improving CPI scores to satisfy EU accession requirements demonstrates that Montenegro's political establishment is oriented toward pleasing Brussels rather than serving the interests of Montenegrin citizens. The DF and DNP bloc contends that corruption should be addressed because it harms Montenegrin society, not because Transparency International assigns a number that European Commission officials reference in progress reports.

However, the DF and DNP bloc does not dismiss the existence of corruption in Montenegro. The bloc argues that corruption is a genuine problem that predates and transcends EU integration frameworks, and that effective anti-corruption policy requires strengthening Montenegrin institutions on their own terms rather than importing institutional models designed for different social and political contexts.


VIII. PARTY BLOC REACTIONS -- BS AND MINORITY PARTIES

The Bosniak Party and Albanian minority parties, while holding a smaller number of seats, bring a perspective that no other bloc adequately represents. The minority parties argue that corruption disproportionately affects minority communities through several mechanisms: discriminatory application of public employment quotas, where formal commitments to minority representation are undermined by informal hiring practices that favor majority-community candidates with political connections; unequal distribution of public investment, where infrastructure and services in minority-populated municipalities receive less funding through opaque allocation processes; and barriers to accessing justice, where minority community members face linguistic, cultural, and institutional obstacles to reporting corruption and pursuing complaints through official channels.

The minority parties note that the CPI methodology does not disaggregate corruption perceptions by ethnic community, meaning that the specific corruption experiences of Bosniaks, Albanians, and other minority groups in Montenegro are invisible in the aggregate score. The minority parties call for the development of minority-specific anti-corruption assessments and the establishment of multilingual reporting mechanisms that enable citizens from all communities to report corruption in their own languages.

The minority parties express conditional support for the overall positive assessment of the CPI ranking but insist that any national anti-corruption strategy must explicitly address the intersection of corruption with ethnic discrimination and ensure that anti-corruption reforms benefit all communities equitably.


IX. CROSS-CUTTING THEMES AND POINTS OF CONSENSUS

Despite significant differences in emphasis and interpretation, the Parliament identifies the following points on which all blocs and all ministries broadly converge:

1. A CPI score of 46 out of 100 is insufficient for a country pursuing EU membership and aspiring to European governance standards. No party bloc, including the ruling coalition, claims otherwise.

2. Complacency and political self-congratulation would be counterproductive regardless of regional comparisons. Being the least corrupt country in the Western Balkans is a relative achievement that carries no weight in absolute terms.

3. The CPI is a perception-based metric with significant methodological limitations. It does not measure enforcement outcomes, sector-specific corruption dynamics, or citizen-level corruption experiences. Policy should not be driven by the CPI score alone.

4. Concrete, time-bound improvement targets in the range of CPI 50 to 55 by 2028 to 2030 should be established, accompanied by sector-specific enforcement metrics.

5. Sector-specific corruption risks in healthcare, education, construction and spatial planning, police integrity, public procurement, and environmental permitting require targeted interventions that the aggregate CPI framework does not adequately address.

6. The gap between legislative frameworks and enforcement outcomes, particularly the absence of high-level corruption convictions, remains Montenegro's most significant anti-corruption credibility deficit.


X. POINTS OF CONTENTION

The Parliament records the following unresolved disagreements:

1. Whether the CPI score of 46 represents meaningful progress under the current government or stagnation that contradicts the ruling coalition's anti-corruption promises.

2. Whether the CPI methodology is a legitimate governance benchmark or a Western-centric metric that serves EU integration politics rather than genuine anti-corruption objectives.

3. Whether the priority should be improving the aggregate CPI score through broad institutional reform or addressing sector-specific corruption through targeted enforcement in healthcare, education, environment, and construction.

4. Whether Montenegro should actively market its regional CPI leadership for economic and tourism purposes or exercise restraint in promoting a score that remains well below EU standards.

5. Whether the absence of high-level corruption convictions reflects prosecutorial incapacity, political interference, or the structural difficulty of building cases that meet evidentiary standards in a small, interconnected society.


XI. OVERALL PARLIAMENTARY ASSESSMENT

This Parliament finds that Montenegro's 65th place ranking on the 2025 Corruption Perceptions Index with a score of 46 out of 100 represents a cautiously positive result that merits acknowledgment without celebration. The result confirms Montenegro's position as the governance leader in the Western Balkans, which carries real economic and diplomatic value. At the same time, the result exposes the significant distance Montenegro must still travel to meet the governance standards expected of an EU member state.

The Parliament notes that the ruling coalition's governance reforms have contributed to maintaining and marginally improving Montenegro's position, but that the reform trajectory must accelerate significantly to close the 18-point gap with the EU average. The Parliament further notes that the opposition's critique regarding enforcement deficits is substantively valid and must be addressed through concrete improvements in prosecutorial outcomes.

The Parliament endorses the consensus recommendation across all ministries to establish a CPI target of 50 to 55 by 2028, accompanied by sector-specific enforcement benchmarks, annual public reporting on prosecution and conviction rates for corruption offenses, and development of supplementary assessment tools that capture citizen-level corruption experiences not reflected in the CPI methodology.

The Parliament records that eight ministries assessed the result as positive and two assessed it as neutral. No ministry assessed it as negative. The overall verdict is positive, with the explicit caveat that this assessment is contingent on the government translating this result into accelerated reform rather than treating it as validation of the status quo.

The Parliament calls on the government to present a detailed anti-corruption acceleration plan within 90 days, incorporating the recommendations of all ten ministries, with measurable targets, clear timelines, and accountability mechanisms. The CPI score of 46 is not a destination. It is a waypoint that must lead somewhere better.

Record of proceedings closed. All ministry assessments entered into the parliamentary record in full.

PARLIAMENTARY DEBATE TRANSCRIPT
Skupstina Crne Gore -- Plenary Session
Subject: Montenegro's Ranking on the Transparency International Corruption Perceptions Index 2025
Date: February 2026


I. OPENING -- FRAMING THE DISCUSSION

This session convenes to examine the assessments of ten government ministries regarding Montenegro's placement on the 2025 Corruption Perceptions Index published by Transparency International. The facts are as follows: Montenegro ranks 65th globally with a score of 46 out of 100, representing the highest score among Western Balkan countries. The EU average stands at approximately 64 out of 100. Montenegro's score represents continuity rather than dramatic change from recent years.

The Parliament has received assessments from the following ministries: Finance (7 out of 10, positive), Tourism (7 out of 10, positive), Justice (6 out of 10, positive), Interior (6 out of 10, positive), Education (6 out of 10, positive), EU Integration (6 out of 10, positive), Economy (6 out of 10, positive), Health (6 out of 10, positive), Environment (5 out of 10, neutral), and Labour and Social Welfare (5 out of 10, neutral). The weighted average is 6.1 out of 10. No ministry assessed the result as negative, but no ministry rated it above 7 either. This narrow band of cautious positivity itself tells a story: this is a result that is better than bad but far from good.


II. MINISTRY POSITIONS -- THE OPTIMISTIC WING

The Ministry of Finance delivers the most positive framing, scoring the result at 7 out of 10. The Ministry argues that for a small, open economy dependent on foreign direct investment and access to international capital markets, the CPI ranking carries material economic weight. Institutional investors, sovereign wealth funds, and credit rating agencies reference CPI scores as governance proxies when making allocation decisions. Montenegro's position as the regional leader in the Western Balkans provides a competitive advantage in attracting capital that might otherwise flow to Serbia, North Macedonia, or Albania. The Ministry notes that every point improvement on the CPI correlates with measurable improvements in borrowing costs and investment attractiveness. However, the Ministry of Finance is careful to note that 46 out of 100 still places Montenegro in the lower third of all assessed countries globally, and that the 18-point gap to the EU average represents a structural impediment to Montenegro's economic convergence aspirations.

The Ministry of Tourism shares the 7 out of 10 score and offers a complementary argument. In the competitive Mediterranean and Adriatic tourism market, destination perception matters enormously. Tour operators and cruise lines assess political stability and governance quality when making routing decisions. Montenegro's position as the least corrupt Western Balkan country provides marketing leverage that the National Tourism Organisation can deploy in key source markets across Western Europe. The Ministry argues that the ranking supports the premium tourism positioning strategy, differentiating Montenegro from regional competitors. At the same time, the Ministry acknowledges that tourism-sector corruption, particularly in coastal construction permitting, marina concessions, and hospitality licensing, remains a significant reputational risk that could undermine the very narrative the CPI ranking supports.

The Ministry of Economy aligns with Finance and Tourism on the investment signaling value but broadens the analysis to the business environment. The Ministry argues that the CPI ranking, combined with ongoing improvements in the World Bank's business climate indicators, creates a composite picture that supports Montenegro's pitch to foreign investors. The Ministry is particularly focused on the technology and services sectors, where governance perceptions directly affect location decisions by companies evaluating the Western Balkans for nearshoring operations.


III. MINISTRY POSITIONS -- THE CAUTIOUS CENTER

Six ministries score the result at 6 out of 10, reflecting a carefully qualified positive assessment that emphasizes risks and gaps as much as the headline figure.

The Ministry of Justice provides the most analytically rigorous assessment in this group. The Ministry's core argument is that the CPI measures perceptions, not outcomes. Montenegro has made substantial progress in adopting anti-corruption legislation, establishing institutional frameworks including the Anti-Corruption Agency and the Special State Prosecutor's Office, and aligning its legal architecture with EU standards. However, the Ministry identifies what it calls the enforcement gap: the persistent disconnect between legislative frameworks and actual judicial outcomes. Montenegro continues to lack a track record of final convictions in high-level corruption cases involving senior officials, politically connected business figures, or organized crime networks operating through legitimate institutions. The Ministry argues that until the judiciary delivers convictions that withstand appellate review in cases involving public officials of genuine political significance, the CPI score reflects legislative intent rather than operational reality. The Ministry recommends that Montenegro set not only a CPI target of 50 to 55 by 2028 but also establish quantitative enforcement benchmarks: a minimum number of high-level corruption indictments, prosecutions, and convictions per year, publicly tracked and reported.

The Ministry of Interior adds a dimension that other ministries largely overlook. The Ministry notes that Montenegro's CPI tier includes countries that are not EU candidates and in some cases are not even aspiring to European integration. This company of peers undermines the narrative of Montenegro as a governance frontrunner. The Ministry further notes that police integrity remains an area of concern, with the European Commission's progress reports consistently identifying politicization of police appointments, insufficient internal affairs capacity, and inadequate whistleblower protection for law enforcement officers who report corruption within the force. The Ministry argues that a CPI score of 46 is consistent with a country that has the institutional architecture of an anti-corruption state but not yet the operational culture of one.

The Ministry of EU Integration delivers perhaps the most strategically important assessment. The Ministry warns that the European Commission does not use CPI rankings as formal benchmarks in accession negotiations, but Commission staff and European Parliament rapporteurs reference them in annual progress reports and political assessments. The Ministry's central concern is that year-on-year stagnation at or around 46 will be interpreted in Brussels not as stability but as a lack of reform momentum. The Commission evaluates trends, not snapshots. A country that improves from 40 to 46 over several years receives credit for trajectory; a country that remains at 46 for consecutive years faces questions about whether reform has plateaued. The Ministry further warns that Montenegro cannot afford to present this result as an achievement in Brussels. The Commission expects candidate countries to demonstrate self-critical assessment capacity, and any government communication that frames 46 out of 100 as a success will be noted unfavorably.

The Ministry of Education identifies corruption risks specific to its domain that the CPI aggregate obscures. Nepotistic hiring practices in schools and universities, where appointments are influenced by political party affiliation or family connections rather than professional qualifications, represent a form of corruption that directly undermines educational quality and contributes to brain drain among young academics. The Ministry notes that students and young professionals who witness institutionalized favoritism in educational institutions draw conclusions about the broader society and frequently choose to emigrate. The Ministry recommends that anti-corruption efforts specifically target education sector procurement and hiring through transparent, merit-based appointment processes.

The Ministry of Health raises the issue of informal payments, one of the most pervasive and socially corrosive forms of corruption in Montenegro. Patients making informal cash payments to doctors, nurses, and hospital staff to secure timely treatment, specialist referrals, or simply adequate attention represents corruption that affects ordinary citizens in their most vulnerable moments. The Ministry argues that this form of corruption is poorly captured by the CPI methodology, which relies on expert and business surveys rather than citizen experience surveys. A CPI score of 46 tells Brussels nothing about whether a cancer patient in Podgorica must pay an envelope to a surgeon before receiving treatment. The Ministry recommends complementing CPI monitoring with citizen experience surveys and healthcare-specific integrity assessments.


IV. MINISTRY POSITIONS -- THE CAUTIOUS WING

The Ministry of Environment and the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare assign neutral scores of 5 out of 10, reflecting the most skeptical assessments in the group.

The Ministry of Environment argues that corruption in spatial planning, construction permitting, and environmental impact assessment processes represents some of Montenegro's most economically and environmentally damaging corruption, yet it is largely invisible in aggregate perception indices. The Ministry points to the Adriatic coastline, where illegal or semi-legal construction in protected zones, facilitated by corrupt permitting processes, threatens both environmental assets and long-term tourism revenue. The Ministry notes that environmental enforcement capacity remains severely limited, with insufficient inspectors, inadequate penalties, and political interference in enforcement decisions. The Ministry's position is that until sector-specific corruption in environmental governance is measurably reduced, the aggregate CPI score provides false comfort.

The Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare focuses on the distributional dimension. The Ministry argues that corruption disproportionately affects vulnerable populations: workers in the informal economy who cannot access labor protections, social welfare recipients who face bureaucratic gatekeeping, and minority communities whose access to public services is mediated by patronage networks. The Ministry notes that the CPI's expert-survey methodology tends to capture perceptions of grand corruption and business-environment corruption while underweighting the everyday petty corruption that shapes the lives of ordinary citizens, particularly those in economically precarious positions. The Ministry recommends that Montenegro develop and publish a supplementary corruption impact assessment focusing specifically on how corruption affects social welfare delivery, labor rights enforcement, and access to public services for disadvantaged populations.


V. PARTY BLOC REACTIONS -- RULING COALITION

The Europe Now! and URA coalition, holding the parliamentary majority, frames the CPI result as evidence of the governance trajectory established since the coalition took power. The ruling coalition argues that Montenegro's position as the Western Balkans leader on corruption perceptions reflects the cumulative impact of institutional reforms, including strengthening the Anti-Corruption Agency's independence, increasing transparency in public procurement, and pursuing digitalization of government services to reduce opportunities for corrupt intermediation. The coalition points to the improvement from Montenegro's historical CPI scores as evidence of directional progress and argues that the reform path established under their governance is producing measurable results recognized by international observers.

However, the ruling coalition is careful to avoid triumphalism, recognizing that a score of 46 remains far below EU standards. The coalition argues that anti-corruption reform is inherently generational in nature and that expecting rapid CPI improvements in a small post-Yugoslav state still undergoing democratic consolidation is unrealistic. The coalition commits to a target of CPI 52 to 55 by 2028 and emphasizes that the government's anti-corruption strategy is focused on systemic institutional change rather than headline-grabbing prosecutions that may not withstand judicial review.

The URA component of the coalition specifically echoes the Ministry of Environment's concerns about sector-specific corruption in construction and spatial planning, noting that URA has consistently advocated for stronger environmental enforcement and transparent coastal development permitting. URA argues that the coalition's environmental governance reforms, while slower than desired, are addressing the very issues the Ministry of Environment identifies.


VI. PARTY BLOC REACTIONS -- DPS AND SDP OPPOSITION

The DPS-led opposition, comprising the largest opposition force in Parliament, delivers a sharp challenge to the ruling coalition's framing. The opposition's central argument is that a CPI score of 46, essentially unchanged from recent years, represents stagnation rather than progress. The opposition notes that the ruling coalition came to power on an explicit anti-corruption platform, promising transformational change in governance standards. Several years later, Montenegro remains in the lower third of all countries globally, with a score that would place it among the worst performers in the EU if it were a member state.

The DPS bloc focuses particularly on the enforcement gap identified by the Ministry of Justice. The opposition argues that the ruling coalition has been more effective at adopting legislation than at securing convictions. The opposition points to the continued absence of final convictions in major corruption cases involving current or former senior officials as evidence that the anti-corruption framework remains more decorative than operational. The opposition further argues that selective prosecution, targeting political opponents rather than systematically pursuing corruption across the political spectrum, undermines both the CPI score and public trust.

The SDP component of the opposition adds a social dimension, echoing the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare's concerns about corruption's disproportionate impact on vulnerable populations. The SDP argues that the ruling coalition's focus on macro-level governance indicators comes at the expense of addressing the everyday corruption that ordinary citizens experience in healthcare, education, and social services. The SDP notes that for a pensioner forced to pay informally for medical treatment or a young graduate whose job prospects depend on party connections rather than qualifications, Montenegro's regional CPI leadership is meaningless.

The opposition collectively calls for the establishment of an independent anti-corruption monitoring mechanism outside government control, publication of annual enforcement statistics including indictment and conviction rates for public corruption cases, and a parliamentary inquiry into why the Special State Prosecutor's Office has failed to secure high-level corruption convictions despite the institutional resources and legal tools available to it.


VII. PARTY BLOC REACTIONS -- DF AND DNP BLOC

The Democratic Front and Democratic People's Party bloc brings a fundamentally different analytical framework to the discussion. The DF and DNP question the methodological validity and political neutrality of the Corruption Perceptions Index itself. The bloc argues that the CPI is compiled by a Western-based organization using surveys of Western-aligned experts and business executives, producing an index that inherently favors countries aligned with Western institutional norms and penalizes countries with different governance traditions.

The DF and DNP bloc argues that Montenegro's obsession with Western governance metrics is itself a form of institutional capture, subordinating national sovereignty and policy autonomy to the benchmarks and evaluations of external organizations. The bloc questions whether the EU's average CPI score of approximately 64 reflects genuinely lower corruption in EU member states or merely different forms of corruption that the methodology does not capture, such as corporate regulatory capture, revolving-door corruption between government and industry, and the role of lobbying as legalized influence-peddling.

The bloc further argues that the ruling coalition's and opposition's shared focus on improving CPI scores to satisfy EU accession requirements demonstrates that Montenegro's political establishment is oriented toward pleasing Brussels rather than serving the interests of Montenegrin citizens. The DF and DNP bloc contends that corruption should be addressed because it harms Montenegrin society, not because Transparency International assigns a number that European Commission officials reference in progress reports.

However, the DF and DNP bloc does not dismiss the existence of corruption in Montenegro. The bloc argues that corruption is a genuine problem that predates and transcends EU integration frameworks, and that effective anti-corruption policy requires strengthening Montenegrin institutions on their own terms rather than importing institutional models designed for different social and political contexts.


VIII. PARTY BLOC REACTIONS -- BS AND MINORITY PARTIES

The Bosniak Party and Albanian minority parties, while holding a smaller number of seats, bring a perspective that no other bloc adequately represents. The minority parties argue that corruption disproportionately affects minority communities through several mechanisms: discriminatory application of public employment quotas, where formal commitments to minority representation are undermined by informal hiring practices that favor majority-community candidates with political connections; unequal distribution of public investment, where infrastructure and services in minority-populated municipalities receive less funding through opaque allocation processes; and barriers to accessing justice, where minority community members face linguistic, cultural, and institutional obstacles to reporting corruption and pursuing complaints through official channels.

The minority parties note that the CPI methodology does not disaggregate corruption perceptions by ethnic community, meaning that the specific corruption experiences of Bosniaks, Albanians, and other minority groups in Montenegro are invisible in the aggregate score. The minority parties call for the development of minority-specific anti-corruption assessments and the establishment of multilingual reporting mechanisms that enable citizens from all communities to report corruption in their own languages.

The minority parties express conditional support for the overall positive assessment of the CPI ranking but insist that any national anti-corruption strategy must explicitly address the intersection of corruption with ethnic discrimination and ensure that anti-corruption reforms benefit all communities equitably.


IX. CROSS-CUTTING THEMES AND POINTS OF CONSENSUS

Despite significant differences in emphasis and interpretation, the Parliament identifies the following points on which all blocs and all ministries broadly converge:

1. A CPI score of 46 out of 100 is insufficient for a country pursuing EU membership and aspiring to European governance standards. No party bloc, including the ruling coalition, claims otherwise.

2. Complacency and political self-congratulation would be counterproductive regardless of regional comparisons. Being the least corrupt country in the Western Balkans is a relative achievement that carries no weight in absolute terms.

3. The CPI is a perception-based metric with significant methodological limitations. It does not measure enforcement outcomes, sector-specific corruption dynamics, or citizen-level corruption experiences. Policy should not be driven by the CPI score alone.

4. Concrete, time-bound improvement targets in the range of CPI 50 to 55 by 2028 to 2030 should be established, accompanied by sector-specific enforcement metrics.

5. Sector-specific corruption risks in healthcare, education, construction and spatial planning, police integrity, public procurement, and environmental permitting require targeted interventions that the aggregate CPI framework does not adequately address.

6. The gap between legislative frameworks and enforcement outcomes, particularly the absence of high-level corruption convictions, remains Montenegro's most significant anti-corruption credibility deficit.


X. POINTS OF CONTENTION

The Parliament records the following unresolved disagreements:

1. Whether the CPI score of 46 represents meaningful progress under the current government or stagnation that contradicts the ruling coalition's anti-corruption promises.

2. Whether the CPI methodology is a legitimate governance benchmark or a Western-centric metric that serves EU integration politics rather than genuine anti-corruption objectives.

3. Whether the priority should be improving the aggregate CPI score through broad institutional reform or addressing sector-specific corruption through targeted enforcement in healthcare, education, environment, and construction.

4. Whether Montenegro should actively market its regional CPI leadership for economic and tourism purposes or exercise restraint in promoting a score that remains well below EU standards.

5. Whether the absence of high-level corruption convictions reflects prosecutorial incapacity, political interference, or the structural difficulty of building cases that meet evidentiary standards in a small, interconnected society.


XI. OVERALL PARLIAMENTARY ASSESSMENT

This Parliament finds that Montenegro's 65th place ranking on the 2025 Corruption Perceptions Index with a score of 46 out of 100 represents a cautiously positive result that merits acknowledgment without celebration. The result confirms Montenegro's position as the governance leader in the Western Balkans, which carries real economic and diplomatic value. At the same time, the result exposes the significant distance Montenegro must still travel to meet the governance standards expected of an EU member state.

The Parliament notes that the ruling coalition's governance reforms have contributed to maintaining and marginally improving Montenegro's position, but that the reform trajectory must accelerate significantly to close the 18-point gap with the EU average. The Parliament further notes that the opposition's critique regarding enforcement deficits is substantively valid and must be addressed through concrete improvements in prosecutorial outcomes.

The Parliament endorses the consensus recommendation across all ministries to establish a CPI target of 50 to 55 by 2028, accompanied by sector-specific enforcement benchmarks, annual public reporting on prosecution and conviction rates for corruption offenses, and development of supplementary assessment tools that capture citizen-level corruption experiences not reflected in the CPI methodology.

The Parliament records that eight ministries assessed the result as positive and two assessed it as neutral. No ministry assessed it as negative. The overall verdict is positive, with the explicit caveat that this assessment is contingent on the government translating this result into accelerated reform rather than treating it as validation of the status quo.

The Parliament calls on the government to present a detailed anti-corruption acceleration plan within 90 days, incorporating the recommendations of all ten ministries, with measurable targets, clear timelines, and accountability mechanisms. The CPI score of 46 is not a destination. It is a waypoint that must lead somewhere better.

Record of proceedings closed. All ministry assessments entered into the parliamentary record in full.

blind_spots: This is not a government decision at all -- it is an external index published by Transparency International. Treating it as a government achievement to be assessed by ministries is itself a form of self-congratulatory framing that should be questioned.

No ministry challenged the fundamental absurdity of scoring 46 out of 100 and calling it success. In any school, 46 percent is a failing grade. The regional comparison flatters Montenegro only because the neighborhood performs badly.

None of the assessments mentioned media freedom, which is a core input into the CPI methodology. Montenegro's media environment -- including attacks on journalists, ownership concentration, and political pressure on editorial lines -- directly affects both the CPI score and its credibility as a reform indicator.

No ministry addressed the political instrumentalization risk with sufficient force. This CPI result was reported through government-friendly media channels as an achievement, when it should have prompted soul-searching about why the score has flatlined around 44-47 for years.

The assessments did not examine which specific CPI source surveys drove the score. The CPI is a composite of up to 13 data sources, and disaggregating them would reveal whether the stable score masks deterioration in some areas offset by improvement in others.
No ministry mentioned the political party financing system, which is one of the most corruption-prone areas in Montenegro and a recurring concern in GRECO evaluations.

The assessments largely ignored state-owned enterprises, which are a major locus of patronage, inefficiency, and corruption in Montenegro -- including entities like EPCG, Montenegro Airlines successors, and Port of Bar.

No ministry discussed local government corruption, which citizens experience most directly. Municipal governance in Montenegro -- especially in smaller towns -- is often characterized by clientelism, nepotism, and opaque decision-making that the national CPI score obscures.

The role of civil society and whistleblower protection in practice was barely mentioned. Montenegro has whistleblower legislation but enforcement and protection remain weak, which suppresses the reporting that would drive actual anti-corruption results.
critic_report.overall_analysis: This is not a government decision. It is an external assessment by Transparency International that the government has chosen to publicize as if it were an achievement. The independent auditor's first observation is that framing an external corruption ranking as a government agenda item for ministerial review is itself revealing -- it suggests a government more interested in managing perceptions of corruption than in fighting corruption itself. A score of 46 out of 100 means that Montenegro is perceived as more corrupt than clean. Sharing a ranking bracket with Kuwait, Armenia, Namibia, and Senegal is not cause for celebration; it is cause for concern. The fact that Montenegro leads the Western Balkans says more about the dire state of governance in the region than about Montenegro's own performance. Serbia's dramatic decline to 116th place and Bosnia's persistent crisis at 109th set an extraordinarily low bar. Leading this group is like being the tallest person in a room of children. The seven ministry assessments are, collectively, surprisingly competent. They demonstrate genuine analytical engagement rather than pure rubber-stamping. Each ministry correctly identified sector-specific corruption risks, contextualized the score against EU benchmarks, and avoided excessive cheerleading. The Ministry of Environment and Ministry of Labour produced particularly strong analyses connecting the abstract CPI number to concrete governance failures affecting citizens. The Ministry of Finance offered useful quantification of corruption costs. However, there is a troubling uniformity in the assessments: every ministry scored between 5 and 7 out of 10, with most landing at 6. This narrow range suggests either institutional groupthink or an unspoken instruction to be cautiously positive. No ministry gave a score below 5 despite the fact that 46/100 is objectively poor. No ministry gave above 7 despite the regional comparison being genuinely favorable. This clustering around the safe middle ground is itself a soft form of institutional corruption -- telling the government what it wants to hear, with just enough caveats to appear independent. The most critical gap across all assessments is the failure to ask the hard question: why has Montenegro's score been stuck in the mid-40s for approximately five years? Stability is not resilience; it is stagnation. If reforms were working, the score should be climbing. The European Commission has been saying the same thing in its annual progress reports: Montenegro has the laws but not the results. The Special State Prosecutor's Office has produced almost no final convictions in high-level corruption cases. The Agency for Prevention of Corruption identifies violations but prosecutorial follow-through is inconsistent. Judicial independence remains compromised by political appointment processes that the Venice Commission has repeatedly criticized. For EU accession, the CPI score is a footnote. The Commission uses its own detailed methodology under the new approach for Chapters 23 and 24. What matters is not the perception of corruption but the demonstrated track record of fighting it: asset seizures, convictions, institutional independence, whistleblower outcomes. On all of these metrics, Montenegro continues to underperform. The government's decision to publicize this ranking as news, rather than treating it as a diagnostic tool, reveals a troubling preference for narrative management over substantive reform. Citizens who interact with local government offices, construction permitting authorities, healthcare facilities, and courts know that a 46-point score reflects their daily reality more accurately than any government press release suggesting progress.
critic_report.headline: Montenegro Celebrates Being Least Corrupt in a Badly Corrupt Region While Scoring a Failing 46 Out of 100
eu_chapter_relevance: Ch.23 Judiciary and Fundamental Rights -- The CPI is directly relevant to anti-corruption benchmarks under this chapter. Montenegro's stagnant score reinforces the European Commission's assessment that legislative reforms have not produced a credible track record of results, particularly in high-level corruption prosecutions and judicial independence.

Ch.24 Justice, Freedom and Security -- Organized crime enforcement, police integrity, and border management corruption all fall under this chapter. A score of 46 signals persistent institutional weaknesses that affect Chapter 24 interim benchmark compliance.

Ch.5 Public Procurement -- Corruption in procurement is one of the most direct manifestations of the governance weaknesses the CPI captures. Multiple ministries flagged procurement opacity, and the EU requires transparent, competitive procurement systems as a condition of this chapter.

Ch.27 Environment and Climate Change -- Environmental permitting, coastal construction, and waste management concessions are among the most corruption-prone governance areas in Montenegro, directly affecting compliance with the environmental acquis.

Ch.23 and Ch.24 combined gate overall accession progress -- These rule-of-law chapters are opened first and closed last under the new methodology. A flatlined CPI score at 46 provides no evidence of the reform momentum needed to move toward closing benchmarks.

Ch.28 Consumer and Health Protection -- Healthcare procurement, informal payments, and pharmaceutical pricing transparency are corruption-sensitive areas that affect Montenegro's ability to demonstrate compliance with EU health governance standards.

Ch.19 Social Policy and Employment -- Labour inspectorate integrity, social benefit allocation, and informal economy dynamics are all linked to corruption levels, affecting Montenegro's ability to meet EU employment and social protection standards.
critic_report.headline_mne: Crna Gora slavi što je najmanje korumpirana u izrazito korumpiranom regionu, uz poražavajućih 46 od 100 bodova
critic_report.overall_analysis_mne: Ovo nije vladina odluka. Radi se o eksternoj procjeni organizacije Transparency International, koju je vlada odlučila javno predstaviti kao da se radi o vlastitom postignuću. Prvo zapažanje nezavisnog revizora jeste da samo svrstavanje eksternog rangiranja korupcije u vladinu agendu za ministarsko razmatranje govori samo po sebi — sugeriše vladu koja je više zainteresovana za upravljanje percepcijom korupcije nego za borbu protiv nje same. Rezultat od 46 od 100 znači da se Crna Gora percipira kao korumpiranija nego čista. Dijeliti rang sa Kuvajtom, Armenijom, Namibijom i Senegalom nije razlog za slavlje; to je razlog za zabrinutost. Činjenica da Crna Gora predvodi Zapadni Balkan govori više o alarmantnom stanju upravljanja u regionu nego o sopstvenim rezultatima Crne Gore. Dramatičan pad Srbije na 116. mjesto i perzistentna kriza Bosne na 109. postavljaju izuzetno nizak prag. Predvoditi ovu grupu je poput toga da budete najviša osoba u sobi punoj djece. Sedam ministarskih procjena je, gledano u cjelini, iznenađujuće kompetentno. One pokazuju istinsku analitičku angažovanost, a ne puko formalno odobravanje. Svako ministarstvo je ispravno identifikovalo rizike od korupcije specifične za sektor, stavilo rezultat u kontekst u odnosu na referentne vrijednosti EU i izbjeglo pretjerano hvalisanje. Ministarstvo ekologije i Ministarstvo rada su proizveli posebno snažne analize, povezujući apstraktni broj CPI-ja sa konkretnim nedostacima u upravljanju koji pogađaju građane. Ministarstvo finansija je ponudilo korisnu kvantifikaciju troškova korupcije. Međutim, postoji zabrinjavajuća jednoobraznost u procjenama: svako ministarstvo je ocijenilo između 5 i 7 od 10, s tim što je većina završila na 6. Ovaj uski raspon sugeriše ili institucionalno jednomišljenje ili prešutnu uputu da se bude oprezno pozitivan. Nijedno ministarstvo nije dalo ocjenu ispod 5, uprkos tome što je 46/100 objektivno loše. Nijedno ministarstvo nije dalo ocjenu iznad 7, uprkos tome što je regionalna usporedba zaista povoljna. Ovo grupisanje oko sigurnog sredine samo po sebi je blagi oblik institucionalne korupcije — kazivanje vladi onoga što želi da čuje, uz tek dovoljno ograđivanja da bi se djelovalo nezavisno. Najkritičniji propust u svim procjenama je nepostavljanje teškog pitanja: zašto je rezultat Crne Gore zaglavio u sredini četrdesetih već otprilike pet godina? Stabilnost nije otpornost; to je stagnacija. Da reforme funkcionišu, rezultat bi trebalo da raste. Evropska komisija godinama govori isto u svojim godišnjim izvještajima o napretku: Crna Gora ima zakone, ali nema rezultate. Specijalno državno tužilaštvo nije postiglo gotovo nikakve pravosnažne presude u predmetima korupcije na visokom nivou. Agencija za sprečavanje korupcije utvrđuje prekršaje, ali je tužilačko praćenje neujednačeno. Sudska nezavisnost ostaje ugrožena procesima političkog imenovanja koje je Venecijanska komisija više puta kritikovala. Za pristupanje EU, rezultat CPI-ja je fusnota. Komisija koristi sopstvenu detaljnu metodologiju u okviru novog pristupa za Poglavlja 23 i 24. Ono što je važno nije percepcija korupcije, već dokazani bilans borbe protiv nje: oduzimanje imovine, osude, institucionalna nezavisnost, ishodi za uzbunjivače. Po svim ovim mjerilima, Crna Gora nastavlja da zaostaje. Vladina odluka da ovo rangiranje javno predstavi kao vijest, umjesto da ga tretira kao dijagnostički alat, otkriva zabrinjavajuću sklonost ka upravljanju narativom umjesto suštinskim reformama. Građani koji komuniciraju sa lokalnim organima vlasti, organima za izdavanje građevinskih dozvola, zdravstvenim ustanovama i sudovima znaju da rezultat od 46 bodova odražava njihovu svakodnevnu stvarnost tačnije od bilo kojeg vladinog saopštenja koje sugeriše napredak.
blind_spots_mne: Ovo uopšte nije vladina odluka — radi se o eksternom indeksu koji objavljuje Transparency International. Tretiranje ovoga kao vladinom postignuću koje ministarstva treba da ocijene samo po sebi je oblik samohvalnog uokviravanja koje treba dovesti u pitanje.

Nijedno ministarstvo nije dovelo u pitanje temeljnu apsurdnost postizanja 46 od 100 bodova i nazivanja toga uspjehom. U svakoj školi, 46 posto je ocjena nedovoljno. Regionalna usporedba laska Crnoj Gori samo zato što susjedstvo loše funkcioniše.

Nijedna od procjena nije pomenula slobodu medija, koja je ključni input u metodologiju CPI-ja. Medijsko okruženje u Crnoj Gori — uključujući napade na novinare, koncentraciju vlasništva i politički pritisak na uređivačke politike — direktno utiče i na rezultat CPI-ja i na njegov kredibilitet kao indikatora reformi.

Nijedno ministarstvo nije s dovoljnom snagom ukazalo na rizik od političke instrumentalizacije. Ovaj rezultat CPI-ja je putem medija bliskih vladi prikazan kao postignuće, dok je trebalo da podstakne samokritičko propitivanje o tome zašto je rezultat bio ravan u rasponu od 44 do 47 godinama.

Procjene nisu ispitale koji specifični izvorni upitnici CPI-ja su doprinijeli rezultatu. CPI je kompozit do 13 izvora podataka, a njihovo razdvajanje bi otkrilo da li stabilni rezultat prikriva pogoršanje u nekim oblastima nadoknađeno poboljšanjem u drugima.
Nijedno ministarstvo nije pomenulo sistem finansiranja političkih stranaka, koji je jedna od oblasti najpodložnijih korupciji u Crnoj Gori i ponavljajuća zabrinutost u evaluacijama GRECO-a.

Procjene su uglavnom zanemarile državna preduzeća, koja su glavno žarište patronaže, neefikasnosti i korupcije u Crnoj Gori — uključujući subjekte poput EPCG-a, sljednika Montenegro Airlinesa i Luke Bar.

Nijedno ministarstvo nije razmatralo korupciju u lokalnoj samoupravi, sa kojom se građani najneposrednije susreću. Opštinsko upravljanje u Crnoj Gori — posebno u manjim gradovima — često je obilježeno klijentelizmom, nepotizmom i netransparentnim donošenjem odluka, što nacionalni rezultat CPI-ja zamagljuje.

Uloga civilnog društva i zaštite uzbunjivača u praksi je jedva bila pomenuta. Crna Gora ima zakonodavstvo o uzbunjivačima, ali sprovođenje i zaštita ostaju slabi, što potiskuje prijavljivanje koje bi pokrenulo stvarne rezultate u borbi protiv korupcije.

counter_proposal.title: From Perception to Performance: A Cross-Sector Anti-Corruption Accountability Framework
counter_proposal.executive_summary: Rather than treating Montenegro's top Western Balkans CPI ranking as a standalone achievement, the AI Government would launch a unified, cross-sector anti-corruption accountability framework that converts the positive perception signal into measurable institutional performance across all governance domains. The framework anchors anti-corruption reform in concrete outputs — prosecutorial track records, procurement savings, sector-specific transparency platforms, and EU accession benchmarks — ensuring that the CPI score of 46 becomes a floor for demonstrable improvement rather than a ceiling for political messaging.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal:
The core of this counter-proposal is a National Anti-Corruption Performance System built on three pillars: institutional accountability, sector-specific transparency, and fiscal dividend capture. This structure draws primarily from the Ministry of Justice and Ministry of Finance proposals as the backbone, since the CPI ranking is fundamentally a governance and fiscal credibility issue, while integrating targeted sectoral initiatives from the remaining five ministries.

Pillar One: Institutional Accountability and Prosecution Track Record. The Ministry of Justice's proposal for an Anti-Corruption Performance Dashboard forms the foundation. This dashboard would publish semi-annual data on indictments filed, conviction rates in high-level corruption cases, average case duration, assets recovered, and the implementation rate of Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK) recommendations. Critically, this dashboard would be formally integrated into the Chapter 23 Action Plan as a voluntary benchmark commitment, as proposed by the Ministry of EU Integration. The dashboard would be presented to the European Commission at the next intergovernmental conference alongside the CPI result, demonstrating that Montenegro distinguishes between perception metrics and substantive reform outcomes. An independent review mechanism involving civil society organizations such as MANS and the Centre for Democratic Transition, along with international experts, would assess whether ASK recommendations are being acted upon by prosecutors and courts. The government would publicly commit to a CPI target trajectory: 50 by 2028, 55 by 2030, with these targets linked to specific institutional reform milestones in the EU accession negotiation framework.

Pillar Two: Sector-Specific Transparency Platforms. Rather than creating isolated transparency initiatives in each ministry, the counter-proposal establishes a unified Open Governance Data Architecture with sector-specific modules. This resolves the potential conflict between ministries each proposing separate transparency portals by creating a single technical infrastructure with domain-specific interfaces. The platform would include the following modules. First, an Environmental Governance Module publishing all Environmental Impact Assessments, coastal construction permits, waste management contracts, and national park concession documents in real time, as proposed by the Ministry of Environment. This directly addresses the most visible corruption vulnerabilities in Montenegro's EU Chapter 27 negotiations. Second, a Public Procurement Module covering all government contracts above 50,000 EUR with mandatory beneficial ownership disclosure for bidding companies, real-time contract performance tracking, and open-data publication of all awarded contracts. This combines the Ministry of Finance's e-procurement mandate with the Ministry of Economy's beneficial ownership transparency requirement. Third, a Health Sector Module publishing medical equipment and pharmaceutical purchases above 5,000 EUR and RFZO drug list decisions with published methodology, as proposed by the Ministry of Health. Fourth, an Education Module requiring University of Montenegro faculties to publish annual transparency reports and establishing standardized teacher recruitment scoring visible to the public, drawing from the Ministry of Education's proposal. Fifth, a Social Protection Module digitizing social benefit allocation decisions from Centres for Social Work and publishing Fond PIO financial data, as proposed by the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare. Sixth, a Tourism Governance Module publishing coastal construction permits, beach concession awards, and short-term rental registration data through a national eVisitor-style system, drawing from the Ministry of Tourism's proposal. This unified architecture is more cost-effective and technically coherent than seven separate portals. It builds on existing e-government infrastructure and can be developed incrementally, with the procurement and environmental modules prioritized given their direct relevance to EU accession chapters.

Pillar Three: Fiscal Dividend Capture. The Ministry of Finance's proposal to quantify and capture the fiscal cost of corruption provides the economic rationale for the entire framework. An independent fiscal impact assessment would estimate the budgetary cost of corruption in public procurement (estimated at 50 to 150 million EUR annually based on international benchmarks), tax revenue lost to the informal economy, and the risk premium on sovereign borrowing attributable to governance perception. The inter-ministerial anti-corruption fiscal task force, co-chaired by the Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Justice, would report quarterly to Parliament on fiscal savings from anti-corruption measures. A risk-based tax audit system using data analytics would target the grey economy with a goal of increasing VAT collection efficiency by 3 percentage points within two years. The favorable CPI ranking would be actively used in Eurobond issuances and investor roadshows to negotiate tighter sovereign debt spreads.

Cross-Cutting Institutional Reforms. Several ministry proposals converge on common institutional needs that should be addressed at the government level rather than in silos. First, the police integrity testing program proposed by the Ministry of Interior would be fully operationalized, with results feeding into the Anti-Corruption Performance Dashboard. Second, a unified whistleblower protection framework would cover all sectors — health workers reporting informal payments, education employees reporting irregular hiring, seasonal tourism workers reporting wage theft, and factory workers reporting safety violations — leveraging the existing Law on Prevention of Corruption rather than creating sector-specific mechanisms. Third, mandatory conflict-of-interest declarations would be extended to all officials involved in high-value discretionary decisions across spatial planning, environmental permitting, healthcare procurement, education appointments, and tourism concessions. Fourth, anti-corruption and institutional integrity content would be integrated into the secondary school civic education curriculum, as proposed by the Ministry of Education, building long-term cultural foundations for governance improvement.

Trade-offs and Resolved Conflicts. The Ministry of Tourism and Ministry of Economy both proposed using the CPI ranking as a marketing asset, while the Ministry of Justice and Ministry of EU Integration cautioned against treating it as an achievement. The synthesis resolves this by allowing investment promotion and destination marketing to reference the regional ranking, while requiring that all government communications pair the ranking with the concrete reform agenda and CPI improvement targets. The government would not claim the ranking as a reform success but as evidence of a credible direction of travel. Several ministries proposed separate anti-corruption units or task forces within their domains. Rather than proliferating institutional structures, the synthesis consolidates these into a single inter-ministerial task force with sector-specific working groups, reducing coordination costs and avoiding bureaucratic fragmentation. The Ministry of Environment proposed an Environmental Ombudsman, which would require new legislation. Given institutional capacity constraints, this is deferred to a second phase, with the environmental transparency module and strengthened inspection services serving as immediate substitutes.
